outline: A triangle pointing to the right means the direction towards the right.
A sign with a sloping line towards right-forward means the right-forward diagonal direction.

In turns the shape of the sign shows what should happen, i.e. first, the fact that one should turn and, second, the direction in which one should turn. Figure 3 shows the sign for a turn to the right.
The shading of the direction sign is part of the form of the sign. This expresses the level and, thereby, the third dimension.

detail.content: High direction signs are hatched.
Medium level is indicated by a dot in an otherwise empty direction sign.
Low direction signs are filled in in black.

keywords: vertical dotted lines (passive or resulting movements)
action stroke (vertical lines of various lengths in the inner and outer columns of the staff)
outline: The action stroke, a vertical line, is also a movement sign.

detail.content: The action stroke, a vertical line, is also a movement sign. It represents an unspecified movement.
The dotted action stroke is the way of writing passive or resulting movements. *See* 126b, 543h, 550k, 744a, 745b,c,d.

outline: Kinetography is written and read *from below upwards*.

detail.content: All movements found one above the other in the reading direction occur one after the other, as with single tones in a melody. *See* 748b, 895a.
All movements written one beside another occur at the same moment, as with single tones in a chord. *See* 748c and *compare with* 895h.

outline: The length of the symbol indicates how long the movement lasts.

detail.content: For example, if a centimetre is chosen for the length of a crochet (quarter note), a semi-breve (whole note) will be 4 cm long, a minim (half note) 2 cm, a crochet 1 cm, a quaver (eighth note) 0.5 cm, and so on.

outline: One can actually see the rhythm in the kinetogram and understand it even if one does not understand music notes.

keywords: direction of reading and writing (reading direction, writing direction)
upper body (upper part of the body)
columns for the upper body (columns for the upper part of the body)
outline: Laban took over the five-lined staff from music notation, but turned it 90 degrees, standing it on end. From this staff only the first, third, and fifth lines are written. The second and fourth lines, together with an indefinite number of subsidiary lines to the right and left of the staff, are imaginary. These imaginary lines are shown as dotted lines in Figure 9. The spaces between two drawn or imaginary lines are called columns.

detail.content: The middle line of the staff is regarded as the middle line of the body. The movements of the right body half are written to the right of the middle line, and those of the left body half are written to the left. On both sides the columns are numbered outwards from the middle line.

The first columns, immediately right and left of the middle line, are for the notation of the movements of the body as a whole, i.e. progression of the body as a whole with steps and jumps, and turns of the body as a whole.
The second columns are called the leg gesture columns. In these columns are written the movements of the legs when they are not carrying the body weight.
The third columns are used for the notation of right and left “upper part of the body” movements.
The fourth columns are used for the notation of the movements of the arms.

If additional symbols such as pin signs, signs for touching the floor, or dynamic signs must be inserted between the first and second columns, i.e. between the support column and the leg gesture column, an unnumbered “inner subsidiary column” can be inserted (Figures 9′, 895f). *Examples* under 486c,d, 487b, 499a,b, 503a,b, 556a,b.)
Likewise, an unnumbered “outer subsidiary column” can be inserted between the third and fourth columns, i.e. between the upper body column and the arm gesture column (Figures 9″, 895g).

outline: Four fairly quick steps forward are made while the right arm is lifted slowly to the right, and the left arm is lifted at medium speed forwards and then high.

There are three basic shapes of pin signs (Figure 17) and two variations (Figure 18). The basic task of pin signs is to show the situation of one part of the body in relation to another. For example, in the fifth ballet position one foot is in front and the other is behind. In addition to this task, pin signs have many others to fulfil, so that they appear very often in the kinetograms.

In addition to this task, pin signs have many others to fulfil, so that they appear very often in the kinetograms.

outline: The signs for touching the ﬂoor with different parts of the foot are derived from the much sign. These signs can also describe which part of the foot is taking the weight while standing or stepping.

detail.content: Figures 52a—d show the four basic types of these signs:
Touching with the tip of the toe.
Touching with the ball of the foot.
Touching with the whole sole.
Touching with the heel.
A variation of the above signs: standing on 3/4 point, or a touch of the ﬂoor with the corresponding part of the foot.

outline: Horizontal brackets which describe how different parts of the score belong together. These signs can, therefore, be considered as variations of the relation signs.
Horizontal connecting line
In some cases the vertical brackets can also be considered as relation signs which indicate that two or more symbols belong together. The curved vertical bracket serves various purposes.

keywords: vertical bows with straight midddle part (inclusion bow)
outline: In some cases the vertical brackets can also be considered as relation signs which indicate that two or more symbols belong together. The curved vertical bracket with a straight centre part expresses the participation of a body part in a main movement. Therefore, it is called the “inclusion bow”.

In some cases the vertical brackets can also be considered as relation signs which indicate that two or more symbols belong together. The angular vertical bracket is the symbol for the addition of a second piece of information to a main movement symbol. Therefore, it is called the “addition bracket”.

In some cases the vertical brackets can also be considered as relation signs which indicate that two or more symbols belong together. In general the “caret” means “the same”, e.g. the same body part, at the same spot, or the continuation of the same movement.

In some cases the vertical brackets can also be considered as relation signs which indicate that two or more symbols belong together. The small vertical angular bracket is called “the staple”, and expresses remaining at or returning to the same point of support. *See* 208b, 560c—e.
Kinetography has no ﬁxed signs for objects. When necessary, symbols for objects are invented and explained in the kinetogram, e.g. Figure 60 shows a chair.

Kinetography has no ﬁxed signs for objects. When necessary, symbols for objects are invented and explained in the kinetogram. The ﬂoor is also considered to be an object (*see* 505c).

outline: The narrow sign (*see* 63) can be varied to express three-dimensional closing, the direction of a contraction and the direction of bending.

Variation by adding lines beside the basic sign to express the direction of a contraction.

outline: Expressing the duration of a gradual change of state. The duration of a movement is shown by the length of the symbol (*see* 7). Therefore, Kinetography has no actual time measurement signs, but only the length of the symbols and the length of the gaps between symbols.

detail.content: The duration of a gradual change of state is shown by:
The length of the direction sign.
The length of the turn sign.
The length of the path sign.
The length of the action stroke. *See* 5a,b.
Also, the addition bracket (*see* 57) and the inclusion bow (*see* 56) in most cases show the duration of a gradual change by their length.
Inclusion bow
Addition bracket

The idea of validity, that is, how long an instruction given by a symbol should be observed. The instructions given by the chief symbols, i.e. direction, turn, and path signs (74a—c), are definite. The state indicated by them is kept until a new indication cancelling it appears. Also, those changes indicated by an action stroke (74d), an inclusion bow (74e), or an addition bracket (74f) remain valid until the next indication cancelling them appears.

outline: If the length of the symbol in question cannot be varied, the gradual change is either written with an increase (75a) or decrease sign (75b), or by placing the symbol above an action stroke and uniting it with the stroke by a vertical bow (75c).

detail.content: Increase sign.
Decrease sign.
Placing the symbol above an action stroke and uniting it with the stroke by a vertical bow.

keywords: body signs (parts of the body) in a vertical bow
outline: The passing change of a state is expressed by a vertical bow which contains symbols of various kinds. Note that all indications written with a vertical bow, however, have only a limited validity.

keywords: as fast and as often as possible
outline: Note that all indications written with a trill sign (77a) or an accent sign (77b), however, have only a limited validity.
Retention signs.

detail.content: The idea of retention. In our system of notation retention is defined as maintaining a state, and in this book the word retention is always used in the sense of this definition. In studying the paragraphs on the various types of retention, it will be noticed that in Kinetography a retention does not always denote the complete absence of movement of a person or body part. As a rule, the absence of symbols, i.e. a gap in the kinetogram, signifies a retention. However, retention signs are used in special cases.

Retention sign in the case of standing still, that is, maintaining the weight on a given part of the body and in the case of “retention in the body”, which is written with the same symbol and consists of maintaining a given angle between two body parts.
Retention sign in the case of “retention in space”, which consists of the maintenance of a body part in the same compass direction.
Retention sign in the case of “retention at a spot”, which means that a part of the body remains fixed on a certain spot.
The “retention at a spot of relationship” is a variety of 78c, which can be recognised by the fact that the retention sign is placed above the relation sign.

outline: Cancellation signs.

detail.content: The cancellation of an instruction. As a rule, the instruction given by a symbol is cancelled by the next contradicting instruction for the same part of the body. In special cases, cancellation signs are written.
The general cancellation sign of Kinetography is the decrease sign, which is derived from the music decrescendo sign.

Twists of the body parts are cancelled by a symbol which is a combination of the symbols for turning to the right and left, which indicates the return of the body part in question to the normal, untwisted state.
The end of a relationship, e.g. the release of a contact, is expressed by a special cancellation sign derived from the retention sign (the broken retention sign). It can be designed in two ways:
End of relationship, way one.
End of relationship, way two.

outline: The timing significance of the horizontal relation signs (*see* 48–52).

detail.content: These symbols play a role in the description of timing only in so far as their placement in the kinetogram denotes the moment at which the relationship is accomplished. Because these signs are horizontal they cannot indicate whether the established relationship is m aintained or not.

detail.content: The reprise signs show the beginning and end of a sequence which will be performed again later.

keywords: levels of support on the feet
outline: Level of supports.

detail.content: High supports are performed on the toes and ball of the foot, with heels raised and knees stretched. (Technical term in classical dance: on half-point.)
Medium level supports are performed on the whole foot with straight knees.

Low supports are performed on the whole foot with slightly bent knees. (Technical term: demi plié.) It should be noted that there is no standard definition for the depth of the demi plié. (*Compare with* 165.)

keywords: different shading within a single sign
outline: If two levels are written within one sign, the movement should be fluent and curved (legato).

detail.content: While the stepping leg bends and stretches, the body is carried steadily forward.
The body is carried steadily forward while it is lifted on to half-point and lowered to medium level.
In gestures different levels written within one sign also indicate a curved shape and a smooth flow of movement (legato).

keywords: different shading within a single sign
outline: One must be careful to distinguish between a single sideways direction sign containing two levels (113a) and two different diagonal signs (113b).

detail.content: The path is over right-high to right-medium.
The path is to left-backward-high and then to left-forward.
One m ust also be careful to divide two direction signs clearly from each other if their straight edges meet, as in Figure 113b, so that they are not read as a single sign, as in Figure 113a.

outline: In steps, the division into separate signs indicates that the movement is angular and less smooth. In this example the body weight is already completely shifted forward during the low step, and the transition to the medium level of support occurs in place.

detail.content: In gestures, an uninterrupted flow of movement is intended if the direction signs follow each other without a gap.
The addition of the vertical phrasing bow means, first, that the smooth flow of movement is stressed and, second, that several movements belong together as a unit, a motif.
An abrupt (staccato) movement is shown by widening the gaps between the individual signs.
In gestures, a small vertical bow which unites two direction signs means that the angular shape is rounded off. *See* 557c,d.
If the angle between two directions is 90 degrees or less (*see* 115a–c), the curved performance of the gesture is understood.

If the hand should travel to its new destination on a straight line, the symbol for a straight path (*see* 260e) is added beside the arm gesture sign and united with it by a vertical bow (115e). (*See* 380g,g′, 557e, 563k, 711d, 760h.)

outline: The “place” sign.

detail.content: In the support column the “place” sign indicates a step with which the body does not move away from the spot. With the second step of this example the left foot moves to place, i.e. beside the right foot. There are high (111a), medium (111b), and low (111c) supports in place.

In arm gestures the “place” sign indicates drawing the arm towards the body so that the hand is close to the shoulder. Note: The same movement or position of the arm can also be described as the sixth degree of narrowness, i.e. the complete contraction of the arm (*see* 656f).

In leg gestures the “place” sign indicates drawing the leg towards the body so that the foot is close to the hip. Note: The same movement or position of the leg can also be described as the sixth degree of narrowness, i.e. the complete contraction of the leg (*see* 660f).
In a starting position graph, two place signs in the support columns indicate the normal upright position with feet together (1st position), standing on the whole foot, arms hanging by the sides.

outline: If written in a gesture column, the direction “high” (117a,b) indicates vertically upward, and the direction “low” (117c,d) indicates vertically downward.

detail.content: In the gesture column the direction “high” indicates vertically upward.
In the gesture column the direction “high” indicates vertically upward.
In the gesture column the direction “low” indicates vertically low.
In the gesture column the direction “low” indicates vertically low.

keywords: detours in gestures (pin signs for deviation in gestures)
pin sign in a vertical bow (position sign in a vertical bow)
pin sign for minute movements (position sign for minute movements, small movements)
outline: In gestures, a slightly curved, passing deviation from the main direction is called a “detour”. In Figure 118 the right arm passes from left-forward to right-forw ard with a slight detour over high. This is shown by a pin sign (*see* 129c) placed within a vertical bow. (*See* 151e,f, 388, 563d,e.)

detail.content: **Directions exactly between two main directions** are written with the two signs of the main directions placed one above the other with a dot placed between them. The direction signs are both shortened so that together they express the duration of the movement. The whole indication is tied together by a vertical bow (*see* 559f), which means that both direction signs together represent one directional indication. In this, example the desired direction is in the middle between forward and forward-high. The technical term is “forward and forward-high”.
An isolated dot with a direction sign above it means move half way to the particular direction.

Two slender direction signs, each the width of half of a column, and written in the leg gesture column mean that the thigh and lower leg have different directions. The direction of the thigh is written on the inside, nearer the middle line. In this example the thigh moves horizontally to the right, and the lower leg moves towards left-low. (*See* 386c and *compare with* 120b, 322f, 352c, 399c′.)

Different directions for the upper and lower arm are w ritten in the same way, with two slender direction signs in the arm gesture column. In this example the upper arm moves horizontally forward, and the lower arm moves vertically up. The full width direction sign placed above this indication shows clearly that the arm now moves again as a unit. (*See* 322f, 352c, and *compare with* 120a, 386c.)

keywords: direction signs with pin signs inside
pin sign in direction signs (position sign in direction signs)
outline: **Finely differentiated directions** are written with a pin sign placed within the main direction sign (*see* 132a–c). This means that the main direction will deviate slightly (one-third of the distance) towards the neighbouring main direction indicated by the pin sign. There are two possible intermediate stages between two main directions. *Example* 121 shows the following directions:

detail.content: High.
High to right-high.
Right-high to high.
Right-high.
Low.
Low to right-low.
Right-low to low.
Right-low.
*Examples* under 441e , 454a.

keywords: direction signs with a retention sign inside (direction signs with a hold sign inside)
retention signs in direction signs (hold signs in direction signs)
undeviating movement towards an aim (undeviating aiming)
outline: For **undeviating movements** retention signs are written within a direction sign. (Retention signs, *see* 217a–g.)

detail.content: A retention in space w ithin a direction sign (122a) indicates an undeviating curve (252a,b, 780a,d) or an undeviating step (256a,b, 780b).
“Retention at a spot” sign written within a direction sign (122b) indicates an undeviating movement towards an aim (780g,h). (*Compare with* 288.)

keywords: direction signs with a retention sign inside (direction signs with a hold sign inside)
retention signs in direction signs (hold signs in direction signs)
outline: **Slide.** The round retention sign is only written within a support sign in order to indicate a slide (*see* 233a, 524b, 780e). The retention sign indicates that the foot in question keeps the body weight while the body is progressing.

detail.content: Before the developm ent of the symbol for the body axes (101c, 889b), the round retention sign was also placed in direction signs for gestures in order to express that these directions should be understood in relation to the body axes. (*See* Appendix 951 and *compare with* the new way of writing in 124g,h, 359d, 391a, 431a, 492a′,b′, 779e′.)

keywords: relating to the front of the performer (standard cross of axes)
axes of individual body parts (body-twisted-part key)
constant axes, axes of a room
outline: **The symbols for the “crosses of axes”** are clefs or key signatures which can be compared with music clefs (*see* 101b–d, 889, and 1002). They indicate the sense in which a directional indication should be understood. If these key signatures or clefs are placed at the left side of the staff, all the directional indications should be understood in relation to the given cross of axes. If they are placed beside or below a direction sign, they are only valid for the body part in question.

detail.content: This is the sign for the **“standard cross of axes”**. It means that the directions relate to the front which the performer has at the respective moment. (For the definition of “front” *see* Note to *Example* 108.) Each person carries his standard cross of axes with him. The cross of axes turns with the body in each change of front; however, it stays upright when the body as a whole or the trunk tilts. The direction “high” always means towards the sky and “low” always means towards the earth. If nothing else is specifically stated, all directional indications are related on principle to the standard cross of axes, i.e. to the front (*see* 108). Therefore, in connection with directional indications, this symbol is only used in order to cancel the relationship to another cross of axes.

This is the symbol for the **“constant cross of axes”**. Constant crosses of axes are the axes of a defined space, e.g. the axes of a stage or the four compass directions which together with the vertical line form a three-dimensional cross. These crosses of axes remain fixed when one moves about, they do not turn when the body changes front, and they rem ain upright when the body or trunk is tilted.

This is the sign for the **“cross of the body axes”**. Like the standard cross of axes, this cross is carried about when one is moving and is turned with every change of front. However, when the whole body or the trunk is tilted, the cross of the body axes is also tilted, whereas, the standard cross always remains in an upright position. When this symbol is in effect, the symbol “high” always means in the direction of the head, and “low” always means in the direction of the feet forward means in the direction of the front of the body, and backward means in the direction of the back; the symbol right means towards the right side of the body, and left means towards the left side of the body.

This is the sign for the relation to the **“axes of individual body parts”**. It is used to indicate the movements and positions of individual body parts in relation to the body part on which they are dependent, e.g. the movements of the head in relation to the chest, or the movements of the hand in relation to the lower arm. In such cases the direction signs indicate which plane or edge of the body part in question inclines towards the body part on which it is dependent. (*See* 343a–m, 359g,i–m.)

Relationship to the axes of a defined space (stage). A body part should be directed first horizontally towards the foreground (parallel with the forward-backwrd axis), then diagonally up towards the right side of the room. (*Examples* under 343n, 359e, 391b, 431b.) (*Compare with* deviations towards the side or corner of a room, 274a–c.)

Relationship to the body axes. Movements written in the kinetogram will be those which a particular body part, e.g. the arm, would perform in an upright body position. If the body as a whole, the trunk, or the chest tilt or are in a tilted position, the relationship between the moving body parts and the axes of the body will be the same as in standing upright. (*Examples* under 359d, 391a, 431a, 491 d, 492a′,b′,e, 493g, 495c, 498d,e, 502d,e.)

If placed in a turn sign, the standard cross of axes means that the body as a whole, or a body section, rotates around a vertical axis while it is not in an upright position. In this case it does not rotate around its own chief axis. Such movements are called “wheeling”. (*See* head wheeling, 43o–q; trunk wheeling, 432k–o; chest wheeling, 436a–d; and body wheeling, 493a–c.)

Use of the sign for the axes of individual body parts. In the case of head movements the direction sign above the clef indicates which plane or edge of the head will incline towards the chest. In this example the face will incline 45 degrees towards the chest. (*See* 343a–m and *compare with* 359g,i–m.)

Clefs written at the left side of the staff, to which all directions in the kinetogram will relate, are valid until they are cancelled by the symbol for the standard cross of axes (124a). Clefs written beside or below a direction sign are valid only for the duration of this one movement. Therefore, the particular clef must be written beside or below each individual directional indication which should be related to this particular cross of axes (124e,g). The consequence of this rule is that clefs written beside or below a direction sign need not be cancelled. If a clef should be valid for several movements of a body part, the clef can be placed in an addition bracket of appropriate length (124f,h).

keywords: diamond around black disk in square
square with diamond and black disc

detail.content: The relationship to **“fixed points”** is indicated by the fixed point symbol (125a). The “fixed points” are located at the outer surfaces of a defined space, and their location is judged from the centre of the room (midway between the four walls, the ceiling, and the floor).
*Example* 125b means a movement towards the point in the centre of the upper edge of the foreground.
The fixed points can also be identified by pin signs attached to the fixed point sign (*see* 126k, 890c–f):
*Example* 125c means the left lower corner of the foreground.
*Example* 125d means the centre of the right wall.

Additional clefs with their m eaning and application are shown under 303–307 (relating to the direction of the path) and under 308 (relating to the general direction of progression, or the line of dance).

keywords: action stroke (vertical lines of various lengths in the inner and outer columns of the staff)
area sign in a path sign
diamond around black disk in square
going away from a focal point
going away from a body part
going away from a fixed point
going away from the point of relation
vertical lines of varios lengths in the inner and outer columns of the staff
vertical dotted lines (passive or resulting movements)
going away from a body part
outline: **Substitutes for direction signs.** The following symbols may appear in the kinetogram as substitutes for direction signs.

detail.content: The action stroke, which signifies an unspecified movement (*see* 5a, 186a, 195a, 246a,b).
The symbol for a passive or resulting movement, which is used if direction and  shape of the movement are results of another movement (*see* 5b, 543h, 550k, 744a, 745b,c,d).

An increase sign indicates approaching an aim and a decrease sign indicates going away from a point of relation if the following four categories of signs are placed in them : (1) area signs, (2) the sign for a focal point, (3) the identification of people, (4) body signs. This way of writing is based on the experience that people and objects appear to grow as one approaches them and to shrink as one goes away.
Approaching an area of a room (*see* 276a,c).
Going away from an area (*see* 276b,d).
Approaching a focal point (*see* 258h), e.g. the centre of a circle (*see* 272a,e,f). (*Compare with* 489g, 491c, 498c–e, 502d,e.)
Going away from a focal point (*see* 258h, 272b,g,h).
Approaching people, e.g. a partner (*see* 276e,g).
Going away from people (*see* 276f,h).
The left hand approaches the right hand.
The left hand goes away from the right hand.
Going away from a fixed point, e.g. from the right upper corner of the foreground (*see* 125c,d).
Pin signs can also be substitutes for direction signs in cases in which they indicate the direction of minute movements (*see* 151a–g).

outline: **There are three basic shapes of pin signs.** In addition there are three wedge-shaped position signs which are used in floor pattern designs.

detail.content: There are three basic shapes of pin signs:
Signs with a small circle (127a) indicate high situations.
Signs with a small cross stroke (127b) indicate medium level situations.
Signs with a black dot indicate low situations (127c).
The first kind of pin signs are also called white pins, the second kind, flat pins, and the third kind, black pins.
In addition there are three wedge-shaped position signs which are used in floor pattern designs to indicate:
The finishing position of a female.
The finishing position of a male.
The finishing position of people without specifying their sex, and the finishing position of objects which have a front side and, therefore, a front direction (*see* 158d–f,j).

outline: Like direction signs, pin signs can be taken as arrows which point in the direction of the small stroke going away from the small circle (128a), cross stroke (128b), or black dot (128c).

detail.content: The situation left-high.
The situation right-backward.
The situation left-forward-low.

outline: The symbol for the high situation (above something) may be composed either of right-high and left-high (129b) or of forward-high and backward-high (129d) to form one symbol (129a,c).

detail.content: Symbol composed of right-high and left-high to form one symbol.
Symbol composed of right-high and left-high.
Symbol composed of forward-high and backward-high to form one symbol.
Symbol composed of forward-high and backward-high.

outline: The situation “in the middle” (inside something) may be represented either by the combination of the situations right and left (130a) or of the situations forward and backward (130b).

detail.content: Combination of the situations right and left.
Combination of the situations forward and backward.

outline: The symbol for the low situation (below something) may be composed either of right-low and left-low (131b) or of forward-low and backward-low (131d) to form one symbol (131a,c).

detail.content: Symbol composed of right-low and left-low to form one symbol.
Symbol composed of right-low and left-low.
Symbol composed of forward-low and backward-low to form one symbol.
Symbol composed of forward-low and backward-low.

outline: Analogous to the 27 direction signs (*see* 103) there are the same number of pin signs. Figure 132a gives a survey of the high situations, Figure 132b gives the medium level situations, and Figure 132c gives the low situations.

detail.content: High level situations.
Medium level situations.
Low level situations.

keywords: pin sign beside direction signs (position sign beside direction signs)
outline: The first (133a), fifth (133b), and third (133c) positions of the feet in classical dance are closed positions; both feet are “in place”.

detail.content: **Pin signs near direction signs indicate the situation of various body parts in relation to one another.** *See* also 133–147.
In the 1st position (133a) the feet are placed in the natural way beside each other; pin signs are not needed.

In the 5th position the feet are also close together, not one beside the other as in 1st position, but one in front of the other with the heel of the front foot touching the tip of the back foot. Figure 133b shows the 5th position with the right foot in front; the pin signs indicate that the right foot is placed in front of the left, and the left foot is behind the right.

In the 3rd position one foot is placed diagonally in front of the other, the heel of the front foot touching the middle of the other foot. Figure 133c shows the 3rd position with the right foot in front.

There is an international agreement that black pins (low situations) are written for foot and arm positions, in spite of the fact that flat pins (medium level situations) would be more logical in most cases. The reason for this is that black pins can be designed more easily and clearly within a narrow space.

keywords: pin sign beside direction signs (position sign beside direction signs)
outline: In open positions the pin signs have the same meaning as in closed positions (*see* 133).

detail.content: **Pin signs near direction signs indicate the situation of various body parts in relation to one another.** *See* also 133–147.
Figure 134a shows a slightly crossed 4th position. As in a 3rd position, the heel of the front foot is placed in front of the middle of the other foot.
Figure 134b shows a 4th position completely crossed. As in the 5th position the heel of the front foot is placed in front of the tip of the other foot.
In comparison, Figure 134c shows an overcrossed position, in which the feet cross still further over towards the opposite side.

There is an international agreement that black pins (low situations) are written for foot and arm positions, in spite of the fact that flat pins (medium level situations) would be more logical in most cases. The reason for this is that black pins can be designed more easily and clearly within a narrow space.

keywords: pin sign beside direction signs (position sign beside direction signs)
outline: Survey of the five ballet positions.

detail.content: Pin signs beside the support signs (133–135) indicate only the situation of the feet in relation to one another, and do not give any inform ation about the directions in which the feet point. The latter is a question of leg rotation and would, therefore, be indicated by a turn sign. (*See* 240e, 396, 397.)
**Pin signs near direction signs indicate the situation of various body parts in relation to one another.** *See* also 133–147.

There is an international agreement that black pins (low situations) are written for foot and arm positions, in spite of the fact that flat pins (medium level situations) would be more logical in most cases. The reason for this is that black pins can be designed more easily and clearly within a narrow space.

keywords: pin sign beside direction signs (position sign beside direction signs)

detail.content: Normal walking is double-tracked, the right foot being placed each time on the right track and the left foot on the left track.
The forward pin signs with a forward walk indicate a single-track path (136b). The feet are placed on the middle line which divides the two normal tracks. This is the movement of a tight-rope walker.
Accordingly, in walking backwards on a single track, backward pin signs will be written beside the direction signs.
The equal signs above the starting line extended to the left, and below the finishing line extended to the right are repeat signs (*see* 796).

keywords: active parts of the body in a movement
pin signs for the leg (and its parts)
pin sign beside direction signs (position sign beside direction signs)

detail.content: In leg gestures the pin sign is placed at the inner side of the direction sign (nearer the middle line). In *Example* 137a the leg is lowered to the 5th position in front after the forward battement, and to the 5th position behind after the battement to the side. However, on neither occasion will the foot take any weight. In positions on both feet (133b,c, 134a,b), both feet are given pin signs. In movements only the active body parts will be given pin signs, e.g. in Figure 137a there are pin signs for the active right leg only. However, in a changement (137b) both legs are involved, and pin signs for both must be written.

A black pin sign which points to the outside, i.e. to the right for the right leg and to the left for the left leg, indicates that the leg is beside the other, i.e. in 1st position. As a rule, this pin sign is not needed, because the 1st position is written without pin signs. (*See* 133a, 135.) In *Example* 137c this pin indicates that the leg is moved through the position beside the other leg (1st position) to the position in front of it (5th position).
In rising to the position on the tip of the toes (sur la pointe) or to the position on the half-point (demi-pointe) in a 5th position, there are four possible ways of performance.
If pin signs are written for both feet, the feet will slide together from both sides so that one is exactly in front of the other.
If a pin sign is written for one foot only, this foot will be pulled towards the other while the point of the latter remains at the same spot.

If one wishes both tips of the feet to remain at their original spot, “staples”, i.e. angular vertical brackets, are written. These indicate that the new point of support is identical with the old one. (*See* 560c–e.) The result is a slightly opened position which has little similarity to the original position. Therefore, in this case no pin signs are written.

keywords: direction of reading and writing (reading direction, writing direction)
pin sign beside direction signs (position sign beside direction signs)
outline: Several pin signs for the same body part are read from the bottom upw ards, like other symbols. In Figure 138 the right foot passes in front of the left and is then placed at the left side of it, where it takes part of the weight.

keywords: pin sign beside direction signs (position sign beside direction signs)
outline: The last example finishes in a “reversed position”. In a reversed position the right foot is placed on the spot which in the normal position would be occupied by the left, and vice versa.

detail.content: Reversed 1st position, left foot in front.
Reversed 2nd position, right foot in front.
Reversed 3rd position, left foot in front; in this position the left foot is diagonally right-forward in relation to the right.

keywords: pin sign beside direction signs (position sign beside direction signs)
outline: In jumps (*see* 192–195), the pin sign relates to the former point of support of the other foot. In the first jump of *Example* 140 the landing will be closely in front of the former point of support of the other foot, and in the second jump the landing will be closely behind. In this connection the pin sign for the last jump, which is composed of the two former pin signs (*compare with* 131c), means that the landing must be exactly on the same spot just vacated by the other foot (*see* 216).

keywords: pin signs for the leg (and its parts)
pin sign beside direction signs (position sign beside direction signs)
outline: In foot, leg, and arm positions flat pins indicate a deviation in the direction shown by the pin (*see* 145). Note: One should remember that black pins indicate the situation of one body part in relation to another (*see* 135–140). Old way of writing: 904.

detail.content: The slightly opened 1st position. The unconstrained, normal position on both feet, in which the feet are vertically below the hips. (*Examples* under 501e,f, 504b.)
Accordingly, in forward or backward steps the same pin signs indicate a slightly straddling walk. The feet are placed on two tracks which are separated from one another by the width of a foot.

In the same way, in leg gestures flat pin signs pointing towards the leg’s own side indicate a slight opening of the leg position. In such a case, in a low leg gesture the leg will hang down exactly vertically from the hip.

In gestures or positions of the arms or legs, the term “to its own side” means that the limbs of the right side of the body move to the right or are directed to the right, and that the limbs of the left side of the body move to the left or are directed to the left.

Figure 141c gives a detailed description of an entrechat quatre by means of pin signs. Starting in 5th position with the left foot in front, during the jump the legs slightly open sideways, they then beat together in 5th position with the right foot in front, and open slightly sideways again before landing in 5th position with the left foot in front.
From 1st position the feet are opened slightly right-forward and left-backward. Therefore, the right heel is at the side of a point situated between the heel and middle of the left foot.
In *Examples* d and e the feet are turned out 45 degrees. (*See* rotation of the leg, 397b.)
A 5th position slightly opened forwards and backwards. This corresponds to a very narrow 4th position (*see* 135). (*Compare with* 485d, 487c.)
A 5th position with parallel feet, slightly opened sideways. As in the 1st position the feet are placed in two tracks (*compare with* 136a).
For parallel position of the feet *see* rotations of the leg, 396c.
A slightly open “reversed” 3rd position (*see* 139).

keywords: pin sign beside direction signs (position sign beside direction signs)
outline: In arm gestures and positions occurring in the sagittal plane (high, forward, low, backward) black pin signs indicate the situation of the hands in relation to the middle line of the body. (*Compare with* 485.)

detail.content: The arms hang down naturally on both sides of the body.
The right hand is situated in front of the right half of the body, and the left hand is in front of the left half.
The hands are situated in front of the centre of the body.
The second pin sign for the right arm indicates that the right hand is in front of the left hand.

In arm positions or gestures towards the opposite side (across the body), the pin signs indicate whether the arms cross in front of or behind the body. In Figure 142e the right arm crosses in front of the body, and the left arm crosses behind. In Figure 142f both arms cross in front of the body, and the left arm is in front of the right arm.
In arm positions or gestures towards the arm’s own side, the pin signs can only indicate the situation of the arm in relation to another person or an object.

In an arm position in the sagittal plane, black pin signs which point sideways indicate the normal situation of the arms, in which they are exactly below, in front of, behind, or above the shoulders. If both arms have the same direction, the distance between the hands is the width of the shoulder girdle. These black pins are used only in extraordinary cases. In *Example* 142h the arms move from a position in which they are spread out sideways, through the normal position vertically down, to the finishing position.

keywords: pin sign beside direction signs (position sign beside direction signs)
outline: Figure 143 is a design to help clarify the special problems of arm movements and positions which occur in the sagittal plane (*see* 142a–d).

detail.content: The oval in the design represents a cross-section of the trunk.

Whereas the legs are closed together in their full length in the basic position (133a), the arms are separated from one another by the width of the body (142a). While in steps we deal with a double-track path (136a), a one-and-a-half-track path (when there are diagonal pin signs), a single-track path (136b), or a slightly opened three-track path (141b), in arm positions and gestures we must consider five tracks, each of which occupies the width of a hand. The pin signs or their absence indicate in which of the five tracks the hand (the whole bulk of the hand) is situated or moves.

In the design of 143 the tracks are numbered from left to right. If no pin signs are written, the right hand will be in track 5 and the left hand in track 1. If diagonal pins are written, the right hand will be in track 4 and the left hand in track 2. If pins pointing forwards or backwards are written, both hands will be in track 3.

keywords: pin sign beside direction signs (position sign beside direction signs)

detail.content: The arms are horizontally in front of their respective shoulders, the whole of the right arm is in track 5, and the whole of the left arm is in track 1.
The right hand is in track 4, in front of the right half of the body, and the left hand is in track 2, in front of the left half of the body.
Both hands are in track 3, in front of the centre of the body.
The arms are crossed over with the hands in front of the shoulders of the opposite side. The right hand is in track 1 and the left in track 5.
The tracks are three-dimensional and extend upwards over the body.
The classical arm position en haut ; the right hand is in track 4, and the left hand is in track 2.
An arm position which occurs in Spanish dances, in which the hands are in track 2 and track 4 behind the body.

In the “slightly opened” position the right hand is above the right half of the head, in track 4, and the left hand is above the left half of the head, in track 2. The two hand positions are exactly in the middle between those positions which are shown in 144e,f. From this results the way of writing the slightly opened position. The pin signs of 144e,f are united to form one symbol.
The hand should be exactly above the centre of the head. Thus, it is in track 3.
In supporting on the hands, the hand positions are also analysed and written in accordance with the rules which are explained in Figures 142–144 (*see* 483e, 485a–d).

keywords: pin sign beside direction signs (position sign beside direction signs)
outline: In accordance with their meaning in foot positions (*see* 141a–g), isolated flat pin signs beside the direction signs (i.e. not within a vertical bow) in arm positions mean a deviation of the arm from the indicated position in that direction which is shown by the flat pin sign.

detail.content: The arms are slightly opened right-forward and left-forward from their normal position beside the body.
The hands are in front of the two thighs, and from this position the arms are deviated slightly forward, away from the body.
Because a position is shown in *Example* 145b, it does not matter whether the two pin signs are written beside or on top of one another.
The arms move into the position shown in 145b. The two pin signs are placed beside one another. Deviating forwards and going into the position in front of the thigh occur at the same time.

The pin signs are placed one on top of the other. At first the arms deviate forward from the normal position, and then they go into the position closely in front of the thighs. Finishing position as in 142b.

keywords: pin sign beside direction signs (position sign beside direction signs)
outline: In movements across the body we read: crossing in front of the body (146a) and crossing behind (146b).

detail.content: Crossing in front of the body
crossing behind the body

keywords: pin sign beside direction signs (position sign beside direction signs)
outline: In progressing to the side, a front and a rear track will result. One can express by additional pin signs on which of these two tracks the crossing step or the open step should be placed.

detail.content: The right foot stays on the rear track, and the left foot remains on the front track.

The right foot is placed on the front track exactly in line with the left foot, the left is placed on the rear track, the right is placed on the rear track exactly in line with the left foot, and the left is placed on the front track.
Both times the right foot is placed in line with the left foot on the front track, the left foot closes in front each time. The path is not exactly sideways, but there is a deviation forwards.

keywords: pin sign beside direction signs (position sign beside direction signs)
pin sign indicating shifts (position sign indicating shifts)
outline: **The use of pin signs in shifts.** Certain shifts of body parts or body sections are expressed by pin signs written beside the direction signs. In such a case the pin sign describes the situation of the particular body part in relation to its own normal position. Other way of writing: 957.

detail.content: Shifting the chest forwards (*see* 423d,e).
Shifting the head to the right (*see* 330).
Shifting the pelvis forwards (*see* 423f).
A pin sign placed in an increase sign is the way of writing a shift of the centre of gravity (*see* 423c, 479b, 488f, 501f, 526a).

keywords: direction signs with pin signs inside
pin sign in direction signs (position sign in direction signs)
outline: **Pin signs within a direction sign.** A pin sign placed in a direction sign is the way of writing finely differentiated directions (*see* 121). This example shows the direction forward to forward-high.

keywords: active parts of the body in a movement
narrow sign in a horizontal bow (grasping, surrounding)
pin sign near an addressing sign (position sign near an addressing sign)
pin sign in grasping and surrounding (position sign in grasping and surrounding)
pin sign in meeting from above or below (position sign in meeting from above or below)
pin sign next to relation signs (position sign next to relation signs)
pin sign near a touching sign (position sign near a touching sign)
outline: **Pin signs near relation signs.** A pin sign placed beside a relation sign (*see* Relation Signs) describes the situation of the active body part in relation to the passive part. It answers the question: where is the active body part? It does not answer the question: in which direction is the progression?

detail.content: In touches (*see* 531a, 544, 546, 548b,d–f), a pin sign beside the body sign indicates from which side the touch occurs. In this example one person puts his hand on the shoulder of another. The hand comes from above. However, this does not indicate anything about the direction of the arm gesture which results in the touch.
The body signs, e.g. hand, shoulder, etc., are dealt with in Part F Body Signs.

In grasping (*see* 570–581a), the pin sign between the body sign and the horizontal bow indicates from which side the hand will approach the body part or the object which is grasped. In this example the hand grasps the cup from the right side, therefore, the palm must face left.

In addressing (*see* 606a,d,e,f, 607, 608, 610, 611), the pin describes the situation of the active part in relation to the passive part. The palm addresses the table from above ; the situation of the hand is above the table, the palm must face down.

In meeting from above or below (*see* 607), the pin sign is placed above the straight part of the addressing sign, which leads out of the staff to the sign for the person or object being addressed. This example shows a person situated above another person while jumping.

keywords: body signs (parts of the body) below a pin sign
curving out parts of the body (bulging out parts of the body, displacing a joint)
detours in gestures (pin signs for deviation in gestures)
pin sign above body signs (position sign above body signs)
pin sign in the increase sign (position sign in the increase sign)
pin sign in a vertical bow (position sign in a vertical bow)
pin sign for minute movements (position sign for minute movements, small movements)
pin sign in a tension sign (position sign in a tension sign)
pin sign below the trill sign (position sign below the trill sign)
outline: **Pin signs as substitutes for direction signs.** Pin signs are substitutes for direction signs if they occur as isolated symbols (151a,b) or if they are placed in the increase sign (151c), in a tension sign (151d), or in a vertical bow (151e–g). In all these cases they indicate the direction of a minute movement. (*See* 331, 424, 526b.)

detail.content: The hands vibrate sideways. (*See* 354b.)
The trill sign, which is placed above the pin signs, is dealt with in 767a–d.

The right wrist bulges out first to the left then to the right. The direction of the arm as a whole remains unchanged, only the wrist is shifted out of its natural situation between the fingertips and the elbow. Both movements are performed with a jerk (accent signs). (*See* 354a,c and *compare with* 387a.)
The same movements can also be analysed and written as contractions of the wrist over the back of the lower arm, and then over the front (*see* 684a).
The pm sign is written in an increase sign (*see* 727b, 758e), therefore, the movement will be performed gradually, the wrist gradually bulging upwards (*see* sketch for 318a).
The pm sign is placed in a tension sign (*see* 732) to indicate the direction of a press or a pull.

A pin sign placed in a vertical bow is a “detour” sign (*see* 118). The arm will progress from left-forward to right-forward on a double curved path (tortillé), curving along the main direction first upwards and then downwards. (*See* 388, 563d,e.)
A circular detour (rond) will wind around the same main movement as 151e.

Small detours can be performed around a position. The hand performs a small circle over right-low, backward-low, left-low, and forward-low. The circle is so small that it cannot be described with direction signs. In such a case the movement is analysed and written as a sequence of changes of situation.

keywords: degree of turn or twist (amount of turn or twist)
pin sign in cartwheel signs (position sign in cartwheel signs)
black pin sign in turn signs (black position sign in turn signs)
flat pin sign in turn signs (flat position sign in turn signs)
white pin sign in turn signs (white position sign in turn signs)
turns to a common front (turns in relation to constant axes, turns relating to areas of the room)
outline: **Pin signs in turn and circular path signs.** (*See* also 153.)

detail.content: Black pin signs written in a turn sign always indicate the degree of the turn (*see* 238). In a turn of the body as a whole the pin sign shows the new front in relation to the old one. In the case of a gesture the pin sign indicates the degree of the rotary movement (*see* 334b,d, 397f, 432b). This example shows a quarter turn to the left.
One should also note the relationship of the black pins to the symbol for the standard cross of axes (101b, 124a), which likewise indicates a relationship to the front.

Flat pin signs written in a turn sign establish a relationship to the axes of a defined space. This example shows a turn towards the left side of the room (parallel to the right-left axis of the room). (*See* 258c, 289, 334g, 432c, 491d, 493h.) Old way of writing: 913.
One should also note the relationship of the flat pins to the symbol for the constant cross of axes (101d, 124b), which likewise established a relationship to the axes of a defined space.

White pin signs written in a turn sign indicate the degree of the twist, i.e. how far the respective body part is twisted away from its normal untwisted state. (*See* 258e, 334a,c,e,f,h, 397a–e, 432a, 439d–f.)
The relationship of the white pins to the symbol for the cross of the body axes (101c, 124c) should be noted. Old way of writing: 905.

It should be noted that a pair of pin signs showing opposite directions when placed in a rotation sign (turn, somersault, or cartwheel sign) indicates the axis around which the rotation occurs. These pin signs have nothing to do with the degree of the rotation. (*See* 499a, 503a.) *Example* 152d means cartwheeling to the right around the right-backward/left- forward diagonal axis.

keywords: degree of turn in circular paths (amount of turn in circular paths)
pin sign in a circular path signs (position sign in a circular path signs)
degree of turn or twist (amount of turn or twist)
outline: **Pin signs in turn and circular path signs.** (*See* also 152.)

detail.content: In the same manner as in a turn sign (152a), black pins written in a circular path a,b sign indicate the degree of the turn and the new front in relation to the old one. But in connection with this they also give information about the shape of the circular path. (*See* 262.)
A 3/4 circular path to the left.
A passive 1/2 circle to the left. (*See* 27a, 260f,g, 744.)

In the same way as in a turn sign (*see* 152b), flat pins written in a circular path sign indicate a relationship to the axes of a defined space. The aim of this circular path is to face the right-backward corner of the room (parallel to the left-forward/right- backward axis of the room).

In the notation of the group movement of “turning inside out” (*see* 300a,b), the pin sign “low” (*see* 131c) is placed in the path sign. In such cases this pin sign means that the leader of the path of the group progresses without change of front on the diameter of the circular line on which the group is arranged.

keywords: degree of turn or twist (amount of turn or twist)
pin sign in a circular path signs (position sign in a circular path signs)
black pin sign in turn signs (black position sign in turn signs)
degree of turn in circular paths (amount of turn in circular paths)
outline: **Combined pin signs in a turn or circular path sign.** Two pin signs starting from the same point is the way of writing one-sixteenth turns.

detail.content: A 5/16 turn to the right.
A 9/16 circle to the right (*see* 259a–c).

keywords: secret turn (diamond around a pin sign)
pin sign in a diamond (position sign in a diamond)
outline: As in a turn sign, pin signs placed in the sign for a “secret turn” show the new front in relation to the old front (*see* 495).

keywords: front signs (facing pins, direction of the front, square with a pin sign, stage direction)
pin sign in a square (position sign in a square)
outline: **Pin signs in front signs.** The front sign consists of a small square in which a flat pin is placed. The small square indicates a defined space, and the pin sign shows the front in relation to the axes of this space. (*See* 854.) Old way of writing: 955.

detail.content: The front is towards the foreground (parallel with the forward-backward axis of the room).
The front is towards the right-backward corner of the room (parallel with the left- forward/right-backward axis of the room).
The front is towards the middle between the right front corner and right side of the room.

keywords: circles (as parts of symbols) around pin signs (pin sign in a circle, position sign in a circle
each couple in couples (each pair in pairs)
outline: **Pin signs in a small circle.** Pin signs written within a small circle are used to identify the sexes (*see* 877 and *compare with* the sign for a number of people, 875, 876).

detail.content: Female
Male
Person of either sex
Couple
Each woman
Each couple

keywords: floor pattern and arrangement sketch (plan, stage plan)
pin sign in floor pattern and arrangement sketches (position sign in floor pattern and arrangement sketches)
outline: **Pin signs in floor pattern and arrangement sketches** (*see* 312, 313a–c).

detail.content: In floor pattern and arrangement sketches, pin signs are used to indicate the front and placement of individuals and groups. Other way of writing: 963.
Starting position of a woman.
Starting position of a man.
Starting position of a person of either sex or an object.
Finishing position of a woman,
Finishing position of a man.
Finishing position of a person of either sex or an object.
Elongated pin signs written in sketches represent the arrangement of a file of women (158g) or men (158h) who are arranged behind one another on a curved (g) or straight (h) line (*see* 313d).

Example of a floor pattern sketch. *Example* 158i is the starting position of a man standing in the left corner of the background with his front towards the left corner of the foreground. *Example* 158j is his finishing position, standing in and facing the right corner of the background. (*Compare with* 313.)
Pin signs without the small stroke indicate the arrangement of women or men whose fronts are unknown.

keywords: pin sign in body signs (position sign in body signs)
pin sign in the head sign (position sign in the head sign)
outline: **Pin signs within body signs.**

detail.content: Pin signs placed within the head sign identify various parts of the head. *Example* 159a means the right ear (*see* 35a, 344, 346).

The upper, medium, and lower regions of the following body parts can be identified with the help of pin signs placed in their symbols : the movable parts of the trunk (*see* 39c,d, 159b, 443r–t), the parts of the limbs (*see* 364i–k″, 395d–e″), the planes and edges of body sections (*see* 442p–r), and the lungs (*see* 445e–h). *Example* 159b shows the lower region of the left back edge of the chest.

outline: Each change of support means a shifting of the weight and, therefore, a *progression of the body as a whole*. The centre of the body, the centre of gravity, is brought vertically above another point of support. Supports are written in the centre columns of the staff (*see* 9). The independent progression of the body as a whole can only be achieved by means of supports.

Direction signs within the support columns indicate the *direction towards which the whole body will move*, judged from the last point of support. In Example 161 from the starting point (**a**) the first step is forward to the new point of support (**b**), which then becomes the starting point for the second step to the left towards (**c**).

A *change of support in place* also involves a shift of the centre of gravity, although this shift is not so obvious as in progression. While stepping from one foot to the other, the weight of the body is shifted slightly sidewards towards the leg which will take the weight.

Direction signs written in columns other than the support columns indicate *gestures*, which, unlike progressions of the body as a whole, are limited to the space that can be reached without moving away from the spot.
*Three kinds of movements of the body as a whole* are written in the support columns.

detail.content: First, the most frequently used is *stepping*, that is, the transference of weight from one foot to the other. Ordinary direction signs in the support columns indicate steps.
*Second, taking support on other parts of the body* (dealt with in Part G). Examples are lying down (164b,b′), sitting down (164c), and kneeling down (164d).

*Third, turns* are also written in the support columns, as they are movements of the body as a whole. While steps create a progression of the whole body, turns create a revolution of the body and, therefore, a change of front. Turns are an essential factor in creating floor patterns. In *Example* 164e the direction of the path is at first towards the foreground and then, because of the turn, towards the right side of the room. Turns are dealt with in Part E III 237–259.

outline: **The level of supports** (*see* 111).

detail.content: High supports are performed on the toe and ball of the foot, with heels raised and knees stretched. The technical term in classical dance is on *half-point*.
Medium level supports are performed on the whole foot, with straight legs.
Low supports are performed on the whole foot, with slightly bent knees. The technical term in classical dance is *demi-plié*.

The level in supporting on other parts of the body, as in sitting, kneeling, lying, moving on all fours, and handstands, is dealt with in Part G (*see* 448, 457, 467, 473, 477c–e). The level of supports in knee bends is dealt with in H 517b,c, 518.

In performing a step, *the preparatory gesture* (similar to **166a**) and *the resulting gesture of the other leg* at the completion of the step (similar to **166b**) are natural results. It would be superfluous to write these two gestures. Therefore, a simple direction sign in the support column is sufficient to describe the whole movement (**166c**).
However, if something unusual occurs during the step, it must be written, *e.g.* *an especially slow leg gesture* (**166d**) or a *touch of the floor* at the end of the step (**166e**).
The small circle in the support column (**166d**) is a retention sign, the meaning of which is explained in Figure 181.
Touching the floor with the feet (**166e**) is dealt with under Part J 534–541.

outline: **Fine points in the notation of steps.**

detail.content: In a normal step there is no interruption in the shift of the centre of gravity during the preparatory leg gesture for the next step. The shift of the centre of gravity lasts from the beginning to the end of the support sign (**167a**) (*a mobile state*).
Here, the leg gesture is notated separately, and the shift of weight is interrupted during the gesture (*a stable state*).
Here, the shift of the weight is continued during the gesture of the free leg (*mobile state*).
If the centre of gravity is already moving towards the aim of the next step during a leg gesture, the centre of gravity sign within a vertical bracket is added (**167d**) (*see* 527).
If a step on to one leg is made at exactly the same time as a gesture with the other leg, a jump-like step is created (**167e**). The technical term for this is *coupé* (*see* 197a).

In a normal step (**167a**) it is understood that the leg is relaxed in a natural way while it passes the other leg on its path from one point of support to the next. This means that the knee is slightly bent during the course of the gesture, and in the case of a medium level or a high step, it is only stretched immediately before the foot takes the weight. This bending and stretching of the knee is not notated. Therefore, *walking with stiff knees* must be explicitly indicated by retention signs above the knee signs (**167f**) (*compare with* 323a, 788a).

outline: Explanatory sketches have been added to the examples of the problems of supports (169–178) and to the examples of the problems of the direction of jumps (201–216). They can be distinguished from floor pattern designs by the absence of a surrounding line. The position signs in these sketches have a special meaning which is explained in Figure **168**.

**169–178** **Problems of change of support.** The key question to ask in all problems of change of support is:  “where is ′place′?” For it is from this spot that the direction of the next step is determined. *Principle:  “Place” is the point vertically beneath the centre of gravity.*

detail.content: In standing on one foot the point of support is identical with “place”. In consequence, after a step onto one foot has been completed, this foot is “on place”, for the centre of gravity is vertically above the new point of support.
Consequently, *stepping to place with one foot* always means that this foot is *placed beside the other*.

The essential factor is always the path made by the whole body (centre of gravity). If there is a change in the step direction, an angle is created in the path. It is understood that the foot takes the shortest way into the first step in the new direction, making a short cut across the corner (*see* the dotted arrow in sketch **170a**).
The extra gesture must be written if one foot joins the other before stepping into the new direction, as in this example, which shows a *pas de basque*.
The narrow low leg gesture (*sur le cou de pied*) is explained in Part L I 660a.
A change of step direction into the opposite direction creates a return to the original point of support, therefore, the motif stays on the spot.
However, if the second foot always follows the first foot to the new point of support (stepping into “place”), progression results.

outline: *Swaying* is the *transference of the weight in opposite directions* with the free foot remaining on the floor. (For the carriage of the trunk in swaying, *see* 425d–g.)

detail.content: The signs for touching the floor which are used in Figures **172a–c** are dealt with in Part J 534–541.
Swaying in 1st position.
Swaying in 2nd position.
Swaying in 4th position.
If there are no signs for touching the floor, real steps take place, *i.e.* the free foot is lifted from the floor. The steps may progress or stay on the spot.
The narrow sign in the leg gesture column of the free leg indicates that the foot is more distinctly lifted from the floor (*see* 660, 661).

outline: *In standing on both feet*, the centre of gravity is above a point between the two feet. Therefore, this point is “place”. In cases of this kind, place must be distinguished from the points of support of the two feet.

detail.content: In open positions on both feet, *the step length is measured from* the point of support of *one foot to* the point of support of *the other*.

In the 2nd position (**173a**) and 4th position (**173b**) the right foot is one step-length away from the left, and both are a half step-length away from place. Also, if the feet are together in 1st position (**173c**), the true place is between the two points of support, at the spot where the two feet touch each other.

outline: With the two principles of “place” (169) and of the width of open positions on both feet (173), all *steps and jumps in, into, and from double positions* can be written clearly.

detail.content: Simultaneously moving to a support on “place”  from an open position on both feet creates *a sliding movement to the centre*.
In *Example* **174a** the feet slide together from 2nd position and in *Example* **174b** from 4th position. Because this sliding is inevitable, it does not need to be specially written.

outline: After standing on both feet in an open position, if one foot should perform a new step, this foot must first be released from the floor in order to be able to move. This means that the whole weight of the body is taken by the other leg, and that the centre of gravity is moved vertically above its point of support, which now becomes “place”. This *preparatory shift of weight* can be expressed with a support sign which is joined to the previous sign by a “caret” (*see* 560a,b). This caret indicates that only a shift of weight occurs but not an actual step (**175b,c**). *Note:* Such a preparatory shift of weight can also be expressed by writing a sign for touching the floor for the leg to be released (**175b′**) (*see* touching the floor, 534-541).

detail.content: The preparatory shift of the weight is understood without a support sign plus caret being written. *Example* **175a** begins in 2nd position. The weight must be shifted to the supporting point of the left leg in the upbeat, so that this point becomes “place”, and the right leg becomes free to move into place beside the other leg.
Here, the same event as in **175a** is described in more detail by means of the caret.
The sign for touching the floor in the right leg gesture column indicates that the right leg becomes free and the left leg takes the whole weight.
In this example the preparatory shift of the weight is emphasised by performing it very slowly.
The right foot crosses over beyond the point of support of the left foot.
From a crossed position the right foot moves to an open position beyond the point of support of the left foot.
The right foot steps in front of the former point of support of the left.
The right foot steps almost in front of the former “place”.
With a large step towards right-forward, the right foot is placed in front of its own former point of support.
Step-length is dealt with in 649.
The feet change places
The same event as in *Example* **i**, but with the preparatory shift of the weight written.
The feet change places
The same event as in *Example* **k**, but with the preparatory shift of the weight written.
In *changing the level of support* in 2nd position (**176a**) or 4th position (**176b**), both feet stay on the same points of support. (*Compare with* sliding together to “place”, 174.)

outline: If *both feet move at the same time* from an open position on both feet, the step direction is judged from “place”.

detail.content: Sliding forward while remaining in 2nd position.
Sliding forward while bringing the feet together.
*Closing to the middle* with two steps.

*Opening to both sides* with two steps. Because “place” is always a half step-length from the two points of support in open positions, it is necessary to take a small (narrow) step in both *Examples* **a** and **b**. (*See* step-length, 649.)

outline: **179–191: Jumps, Standing Still (Retentions), and Leg Gestures.**

detail.content: *Rule I.* A gap in one of the gesture columns means a retention, *i.e.* “no change” (*see* 217, 777–778)

outline: **179–191: Jumps, Standing Still (Retentions), and Leg Gestures.**

detail.content: *Rule II.* A gap in both support columns means a jump.

outline: **179–191: Jumps, Standing Still (Retentions), and Leg Gestures.**

detail.content: *Rule III.* The round retention sign placed in a support column means that the body part shown retains the weight. *Old way of writing: App. I 906

outline: **179–191: Jumps, Standing Still (Retentions), and Leg Gestures.**

detail.content: *Rule IV.* A movement symbol in only one of the support columns means that the body part in question takes the whole weight.
Movement symbols consist of direction signs (**182a**), action strokes (**182b**), and rotation signs (**182c**).
The right leg takes the whole body weight with a step.
The right leg takes the whole body weight with an unspecified step.
The right leg takes the whole body weight for the turn.

outline: **179–191: Jumps, Standing Still (Retentions), and Leg Gestures.**

detail.content: *Consequence of Rule IV.* If a body part which has been supporting is to retain some of the weight during the next transference, a retention sign must be written.
Standing on both legs after the transference.
Standing on the left leg and an unspecified right body part after the transference.
After the turn the weight is distributed on both legs.

outline: **179–191: Jumps, Standing Still (Retentions), and Leg Gestures.**

detail.content: *Consequence of Rule IV* A movement symbol in one support column cancels previous retention signs in both suport columns.
The left leg is released because of the step on to the right.
The left leg is released because of the turn on the right.
The left leg is released because of shifting the weight on to an unspecified right body part.

outline: **179–191: Jumps, Standing Still (Retentions), and Leg Gestures.**

detail.content: *Consequence of Rule IV* A retention sign must be written each time to indicate that some weight is kept on one body part during several transferences on to another body part.
In all three movements in *Examples* **185a,b** the weight is distributed on two body parts.

outline: **179–191: Jumps, Standing Still (Retentions), and Leg Gestures.**

detail.content: *Statement:* As soon as a leg performs a gesture it no longer carries the body weight, therefore, a leg gesture cancels a retention sign previously written for that leg in the support column.

The action stroke means that the supporting leg, and therefore the whole body, leaves the floor, *i.e.* a jump occurs. The diretion of the leg gesture is not indicated. One assumes in such cases that a leg gesture is chosen appropriate to a harmonious performance of the jump.
*Example* **186a** shows a hop. The appropriate behaviour of the take-off leg would be to hang vertically down. This can also be expressed by a direction sign.

outline: **179–191: Jumps, Standing Still (Retentions), and Leg Gestures.**

detail.content: *Statement:* There is no reason to assume that the gesture of one leg cancels a retention sign written for the other leg.
No jump occurs in spite of the gap in both support columns. The retention sign for the left leg remains valid.

outline: **179–191: Jumps, Standing Still (Retentions), and Leg Gestures.**

detail.content: *Rule V.* If one leg performs a gesture after a support on both legs, the retention sign for the other leg means that this leg takes over the whole weight. (*Examples* 187a,b, **188**.)

outline: **179–191: Jumps, Standing Still (Retentions), and Leg Gestures.**

detail.content: *Statement:* Rotation of the legs does not indicate that the leg in question either takes the weight or is released from weight-bearing (**189a,b**).
*Statement:* There is no reason to assume that a rotation sign in the leg gesture column cancels a retention sign in the support column (**189b,c**).

outline: **179–191: Jumps, Standing Still (Retentions), and Leg Gestures.**

detail.content: *Special Note:* In a transition of the centre of gravity into a slanting or horizontal situation, the body ceases to be supported, as in a jump (*see* 523a–d′). Therefore, in the kinetogram of a fall, as in the kinetogram of a jump, there will be a gap in both support columns. One can see from the indication for the centre of gravity that the movement is a fall and not a jump. *Example* **190** means falling backwards into sitting with straight legs.

outline: **179–191: Jumps, Standing Still (Retentions), and Leg Gestures.**

detail.content: A hop is a jump returning to the same foot.
Hopping on the spot
Hopping with progression
A hop in which only the gesture of the free leg is written. The gesture of the hopping leg results from the context. The leg will hang vertically down during the hop.
Here, the gesture of the jumping leg is written, and the retention sign for the supporting leg expresses that it does not leave the floor until the gesture for this leg is written.

outline: **192–196: The five possible jumps.** With regard to the participation of the legs and the timing of this participation in a jump, there are five possibilities.

detail.content: *First*, jumping from one foot to the other, or leaping; technical term, *jeté*.

Figure **192a** shows this jump in a simplified form, and in Figure **192b** one way of performing it is shown in more detail. The sliding touch of the floor made by the leg gesture which initiates the jump should be noted. These touches are dealt with under Part J 550. Note also that in a jump from one foot to the other (*jeté*), the swing of the free leg is usually a preparation for the jump. Figure **192b** is performed in a harmonious energy-saving manner, whereas the jump in **192c**, in which both legs are simultaneously thrown sideways (*écarté*), needs a greater degree of energy.

outline: **192–196: The five possible jumps.** With regard to the participation of the legs and the timing of this participation in a jump, there are five possibilities.

detail.content: *Second*, jumping from one foot to both; technical term, *assemblé*.
Figure **193a** shows this jump in a simplified form, and in Figure **193b** one way of performing it is shown in more detail.

outline: **192–196: The five possible jumps.** With regard to the participation of the legs and the timing of this participation in a jump, there are five possibilities.

detail.content: *Third*, jumping from both feet to both feet.
Examples of such a jump are changement (**194a**) and entrechat (**194b**). Compare with the detailed description of the entrechat in 141c.

outline: **192–196: The five possible jumps.** With regard to the participation of the legs and the timing of this participation in a jump, there are five possibilities.

detail.content: *Fourth*, jumping from both feet to one; technical term, *sissonne*.

Figure **195a** shows this jump in a simplified form, and in Figure **195b** one way of performing it is shown in more detail. We prefer this more detailed description because it shows the behaviour of both legs, and also because the simultaneous take-off from both legs is emphasised. Figure **195c** shows the same jump written more simply.

outline: **192–196: The five possible jumps.** With regard to the participation of the legs and the timing of this participation in a jump, there are five possibilities.

detail.content: *Fifth*, jumping from one foot to the same foot; technical term, *temps levé* (*see* hopping, 191).

outline: **Jump-like steps.**

detail.content: The *coupé*, in which one foot takes the weight at the same moment as the other leaves the floor, is a mixture between a real jump and a step (*compare with* 167e).
