Two or more progressions on the same leg which immediately follow each other result in a *sliding hop*, which also is neither a real step nor a real hop (**197b**) (*compare with* 234). Because the body has no time to leave the floor between the individual steps, one only lifts the weight as much as is necessary to slide forwards.

Also in an *échappé, i.e.* in an immediate transition from a closed to an open position or from an open to a closed position (**197c**), there is no time to leave the ground. In this case also only as much weight is lifted from the floor as will enable one to slide into the new position (*see* 232a,b). Example **197c** shows *échappé* from 5th position (198) to 4th position and back to 5th.

outline: The *height of a jump* depends on the length of time in the air (shown by the length of the gap in the support columns) and on the distance covered by the jump.

detail.content: Only a small jump can be performed in a short time (**198a**). It is possible to jump higher and farther in a longer time (**198b**). In the same length of time a jump on the spot can be even higher (**198c**). *Running* is a series of very small leaps (**198d**).

outline: If *the height of a jump deviates* from the natural rule discussed in 198, it must be explicitly written.

detail.content: An accent sign written in the support column and pointing directly downwards indicates a jump leaving the floor with vigour, so that a *good height* is reached within a comparatively short time (*see* 720d, 521d′, and *compare with* 521d).

Jumps just skimming the floor are indicated by the round retention sign above the centre of gravity sign; technical term, *terre à terre*. This indicates that the level of the centre of gravity above the floor is not changed (*see* 521c).

*Preparatory knee bend and final elasticity* are understood and, hence, are not written. As a rule, the notation in *Example* **200a** is sufficient; however, these details can be added as in **200b**. Only an especially emphasised preparatory and final elasticity must be written (**200c**). *Example* **200c** describes in detail a *pas de chat*.
Jumping to land beside the other foot.
Jumping to the side, followed by a step to the new place.
Jumping forward with the feet together.
The same finishing position; the left foot leaving and landing a little later.
The left foot lands a little later than the right and in front of it.
Jumping into 2nd position (*échappé sauté*).
Closing to the middle from the 4th position.
Closing from the 2nd position to the right side.
Closing to the side with two jumps.
The same result, starting with the left leg.
Jumping backwards in the 2nd position; the direction of the jump is indicated by support signs.
The same jump; the direction of the jump is indicated by a path sign.
Shifting the 2nd position right-forward with a jump.
With a jump shifting the 4th position left-forward.
The 2nd position is shifted a half step-length to the left.
First a jump, then a step, giving the same result as the previous example, except that the right foot carries no weight.
Both feet landing in front of the former point of support of the left.
The same result, starting with the right foot.
Jumping forward from the 2nd position into a closed position.
The same in “position writing”, with the help of a path sign.
Jumping backwards into a second position.
The same in “position writing”, with the help of a path sign.
Opening to the right from first to second position.
The same jump in “position writing” with the help of the staple (*see* 560c–e).
The same result, the left foot starting a little later.
The 2nd position travels to the left in two stages.
Closing to the left, passing the former point of support of the left foot.
Crossing over and jumping forwards in a crossed position.
The same in “position writing”, with the help of a path sign.
Crossing over while jumping backwards.
Jumping from an open to a crossed 2nd position, taking off from the left foot and landing on both.
Changing from a crossed into an open position, starting with a jump on to the right foot.
Jumping from a crossed to a closed position, landing in front of the former point of support of the left foot.
The same result, starting with the right foot.
Jumping from a crossed to a closed position while travelling to the right beyond the former point of support of the left foot.
Travelling to the right in 4th position.
The same in “position writing”, with the help of a path sign.
Opening to the left into 4th position, starting with a jump on to the right leg.
Landing nearly in front of the middle of the former position.
Landing in front of the middle of the former position, jumping in the manner of a *sissonne*.
Travelling one step-length to the right in 2nd position.
Travelling to the right in 2nd position, written with the help of a path sign.
Jumping to 2nd position, landing to the right of the former point of support.
Travelling a half step-length to the right in 2nd position.
Travelling one step-length forwards in 4th position.
Opening to a 4th position to land in front of the former point of support.
Travelling a half step-length forwards in 4th position.

First, the right foot lands immediately in front of the former point of support of the left; second, the left foot lands immediately behind the former standing point of the right; third and fourth, jumping directly on to the spot the other foot has just left. (*See* 140.)

outline: **217–219: The Five Types of Retentions and Their Uses with Supports** (*Compare with* 78a–d and 778–781.)

detail.content: In addition to the retentions which have been dealt with in *Examples* 181 and 183, which indicate standing still or keeping the weight on a part of the body, four other kinds of retentions and one variation of the third kind are known in Kinetography. These other kinds of retention occur chiefly in connection with gestures. The nature of these retentions is illustrated in sketches **217a–d**.

Sketch **217a** is the starting position from which one moves each time into the positions shown in sketches **217b–d**. In each of these three movements the arm observes one of the retentions which will now be explained.

During the movement from position **217a** to **217b**, the position of the arm in relation to the trunk remains unchanged; no movement occurs in the shoulder joint, from where arm movements originate. This maintenance of a body position is called **retention in the body** (also body hold). This retention in the body is written with the round retention sign (**217e**). (*Examples* under 332d, 341a, 357a, 390a, 429a, 430b, 433b, 435e, 492d, 582a, 778j, 779b,b′,d″,g.)

The retention in the body means that no change occurs in relation to the cross of the body axes. The symbol for this cross of axes (101c) contains a small, empty circle. The connection between the two ideas of the retention in the body and the cross of the body axes becomes evident, therefore, in the symbols expressing these ideas.

During the movement from position (**a**) to (**c**), the arm remains in the same spatial direction; at both the beginning and the end the arm is directed towards forward-low. This maintenance of a direction in relation to a fixed cross of axes is called **retention in space** (also space hold). This retention is written with the symbol shown in Figure **217f**. (*Examples* under 219b, 251c, 253a,c, 254a–c, 255, 282b, 323b, 327b, 328b, 332a, 341b, 357b,g,h, 390b,f, 398f, 425g, 429d, 430a, 432m, 434c,d, 437b, 442w, 492c, 503b, 582b, 778k, 779a,d,d′,d″,f,g, 780c,d.)

The retention in space means that no change occurs in relation to the constant cross of axes. The symbol for this cross of axes (101d) contains a small, empty square, while the symbol for the retention in space consists of an empty diamond. The connection between the two ideas of the constant cross of axes and the retention in space becomes evident, therefore, in the symbols expressing them.

The diamond is also found as a part of the following symbols: **(1)** the symbol for the central area of a room (see 862e, 865j), **(2)** the symbol for the periphery of a room (see 863f–h), **(3)** the symbol for an area (see 866), **(4)** the symbols for fixed points (see 125, 890), **(5)** the symbol for retention on a spot (see 217d,g, 778d,g), **(6)** the symbol for the standard retention (see 217i, 778i), **(7)** the symbol for the relation to the front of the untwisted end of the body (see 889f), **(8)** the symbol for the number of a measure (see 883c).

During the movement from position (**a**) to (**d**), the hand remains resting on the ballet bar, resulting in the arm being bent. This retention of one part of the body on the same spot while the rest of the body is moving is called **retention at a spot** (also spot hold). This retention is written with the symbol shown in Figure **217g**. *Old way of writing: Appendix I 907.

In the case of a retention on a spot the small black disc is placed in a diamond (**217d,g,h**, 778d,g,h), while in the symbol for the pelvis (315m, 418c) it is in a square, and in the case of the symbols for the palm of the hand and the sole of the foot (375b, 408b) it is in an open rectangle.

*Example* **217d** shows a case of a true retention on a spot, *i.e.* retaining a body part on the same place, as well as a special case of this retention, *i.e.* **retention at the spot of relationship**. The spot of relationship in *Example* **217d** is the place were the hand grasps the bar. In the kinetogram this retention at the spot of relationship can be recognised by the fact that the symbol for the retention at a spot is placed above a relation sign, in this case above the symbol for a grasp (**217h**). (For further *Examples see* 277a, 288a,b, 300b, 301a, 323c, 332b,c, 341c, 357d,h, 390c,e, 429e, 430c, 431b, 490c, 521g, 524b, 543g,h,i, 549d, 582c, 609, 778 1, 779c, 780g,h, 781a, 786c, 787d, 853k,k′.)

During the movement from the starting position (**a**) to position (**c**), another kind of retention occurs in addition to the retention in space. This is the **standard retention**, in which the relationship of the arm to the standard cross of axes (*see* 101b, 889a) does not change, *i.e.* the relation to the front of the performer is not altered.

Because directional indications relate on principle to the front of the performer, *i.e.* to the standard cross of axes (*see* 108), a gap ina gesture column must logically mean the standard retention. However, experience has shown that many colleagues do not grasp the idea and logic of the standard retention. Therefore, they would analyse and write the behaviour of the arm during the transition into position (**c**) as a retention in space.
If the arms observe the standard retention during a turn of the body, the trunk, or the chest *in a non-upright position*, this retention is not identical with any other retention.
It has been decided that in such extraordinary cases a special retention sign should be used (**217i**). (*Examples* under 357g, and in log-rolling, 492a,b, 779e,h, 889 l.)

outline: **217–219: The Five Types of Retentions and Their Uses with Supports** (*Compare with* 78a–d and 778–781.)

detail.content: **The round retention sign** placed **in a support column** means that the body part in question continues carrying the weight (*see* 181, 183–189). When written in the support column, the round retention sign has basically a different meaning than when it appears in a gesture column, where it represents retention in the body (*see* text for 217b,e). In plain standing still, in which the weight is kept on one part of the body, the differentiation between the three types of retentions (in the body, in space, and on the spot) is not essential; the idea of continued holding of the weight is sufficient.

To round off, it may be mentioned that standing still (**218a**) incorporates all three kinds of retentions, *i.e.* one stays on the spot (retention on a spot), the leg does not change its direction in space (retention in space), and no movement occurs in the hip joint (retention in the body).

However, in Figure *218b*, in which the retention sign indicates that the left leg must keep some of the weight while the right takes part of it, only a “spot hold” occurs. The left foot remains at the old point of support. There is no “space hold”, because the left leg, which was formerly directed vertically down, is towards left-low in the new position; nor is there a “body hold”, because movement has occurred in the left hip joint.

**Gliding supports** are recognised from the fact that the foot keeps the whole weight while the body is travelling. Such a movement occurs in skating. This way of moving can be expressed either by placing the round retention sign in a second support sign (**218c**), or by placing the retention sign in the support column and indicating the travelling by a path sign (**218d**). (*See* 233a–c.)

A small circle placed in a turn sign is the way of writing a *twist* of a particular body part in itself. In this case the small circle does not mean a retention in the body in the sense of *Examples* 217b,e, but the fact that the body part is fixed at one end so that the rotation of the free end produces a twist. (*See* 257 l, 371e, 372a,b, 434g, 435c″.) ** *Compare with* the small circle in a path sign: Appendix II 960.

outline: **217–219: The Five Types of Retentions and Their Uses with Supports** (*Compare with* 78a–d and 778–781.)

detail.content: **The sign for retention in space written in the support column.** In the following three cases the symbol for the retention in space can appear in a support column.

In an **“amalgamated turn”** (*see* 256a,b, 780b) the progression of the body, *i.e.* the shift of the weight from one foot to the other, and the turn occur at the same time. Therefore, the step direction will change. In *Example* **219a**, one begins with a step backwards, which, however, is converted into a step forwards because of the half turn. The symbol for a retention in space which is placed within the support sign indicates that there is no change in the step direction in relation to the constant cross of axes. For instance, if the shift of the weight starts towards the background, it continues towards the background until the end of the step. Therefore, such a transference of weight is called an **“undeviating transference”** (*see* 256a,b). (*Compare with* the undeviating curve, 252, the circular path on a slanting plane, 285c, and the undeviating straight path, 480c, 481f, 491b, 497b′,c′.)

It should be noticed in this case that the turn sign is written at the side of the kinetogram because there is no space within the staff. This is similar to one way of writing a simultaneous turn and change of level of support (*see* 248c,e,f). -

In *a passive retention in space*, the symbol for a retention in space is written in the empty support column. The symbol expresses that the whole body of the passive person, who is carried by an active partner, remains in the same space direction while the active partner turns.

The symbol for a **“secret turn”** consists of the symbol for a retention in space containing a pin sign, and is written in a support column. The secret turn is purely a mental decision to establish a new front; no movement occurs. In this example the secret turn expresses that from the moment it is written the direction that was formerly to the right of the performer is now regarded as in front (*see* 495,470, 456d).

The sign for a *retention in space* is written *in a meeting sign* if the active partner in a meeting has a change of front at the same time. Figure **219d** means that the partner (P) must be on the left side of the active person, judged from the front of the active person before he turns. (*See* 622.) Figure **219e** means that the partner must be in front of the active person, judged from the front of the active person before the turn.

outline: **220–224: Supporting part of the body weight**

detail.content: If both feet are supporting, each carries only part of the body weight. If both feet have the same level of support (**220c**), each takes half of the weight. The centre of gravity is vertically above the middle of the line connecting the two feet. If there are different levels of support (**220b,d**), the foot with the lower level carries more weight than the other. The centre of gravity is now vertically above a point between the middle of the connecting line and the standing point of the foot with the lower level. If one foot alone carries the whole weight (**220a,e**), the centre of gravity is vertically above the point of support.

outline: **220–224: Supporting part of the body weight**

detail.content: *A mixture of a support and a leg gesture* (**221b,d**) is written if one foot carries more weight than the other in spite of having the same level of support. The centre of gravity is then vertically above a point between the middle of the connecting line and the point of support of the foot carrying more weight.
Compare with the analogous way of writing the slight lift of the body weight in preparation for the *échappé* (232b) and the sliding hop (234b).

outline: **220–224: Supporting part of the body weight**

detail.content: If *only one foot takes part of the weight, the mixture of a support and a leg gesture* indicates, first, that this foot does not take the whole weight and, second, that the centre of gravity is not shifted vertically above it. Therefore, the *body* is *not properly in balance*, and either the weight must immediately be transferred onto the other foot, as in *Example* **222**, or the body must fall (*compare with* 523–525).

outline: **220–224: Supporting part of the body weight**

detail.content: Carrying part of the body weight can also be expressed by the inclusion bow (*see* 319c,d, 564). The empty inclusion bow means that the body part normally referred to in the column in which the inclusion bow is now placed participates in a chief movement. (*Compare with* 417a.)

In *Example* **223a** the left step is also partly a leg gesture, *i.e.* it does not completely take the weight. The left leg participates with a gesture in a step, *i.e.* in the movement of the body as a whole. This means that two-thirds of the movement is a step, and one-third is a gesture; or, in other words, the foot takes two-thirds of the weight.
In *Example* **223b** the leg gesture is the main movement, in which the body as a whole participates with a support. In this case the foot carries one-third of the weight. (*Example* under 243c.)

outline: **220–224: Supporting part of the body weight**

detail.content: A similar partial support and unstable condition of the centre of gravity as in *Examples* 222–223 occurs if the centre of gravity has *a retention at the spot* during the transference of weight (*compare with* 524b, 521g).
In *Examples* **222–224** the formerly supporting leg is released during the partial shift of the weight, so that an unstable situation of the centre of gravity occurs.

outline: **225–230: Supporting on parts of the foot.** The same hooks and dashes which when added to a leg gesture indicate a touch of the floor by various parts of the foot (*see* 534) are also added to a support sign to indicate which part of the foot is taking the weight.

detail.content: Examples **225a—w** give a survey of the various *possibilities of taking the weight on different parts of the foot*.
Standing on the tips of the toes (*full point*) with the instep arched.
Standing on *3/4 point, i.e.* supporting on the whole of the toes with instep arched.

Usually the normal high support is considered to be *on half point (demi pointe)*. The weight is supported on the toes and ball of the foot, and the heel is lifted so that there is an angle of 45 degrees between the foot and the floor.
If one wants to be particularly sure that the latter position is achieved, one can write it as in *Example* **225d**.
Standing on *1/4 point*.
Standing on *1/8 point, i.e.* standing on the ball of the foot and toes, with the heel only slightly raised.

The five foot positions shown in **225a–f** can also be performed in a knee bend. In this case the hooks and dashes are added to the black support signs. (*Compare with* 518.) In the case of half point there is only one way of writing.

The various hooks and dashes indicate two things, first, which part of the foot takes the weight, and second, how high the heel is lifted off the floor. In the case of the high (**a–d**) and medium level supports (**e—f**), the hooks and dashes also indicate how high the whole body is lifted from standing on the whole foot.
In *Examples* **225 l—p** standing on the whole foot and four possibilities of standing on the heel are shown.
Standing on the whole foot. This contact symbol is only used in exceptional cases, because in medium level and low supports standing on the whole foot is understood (see 111b,c).
Standing on the heels with the feet only slightly lifted from the floor.
Standing on the heels with the feet lifted from the floor.
Standing on the heels with the feet noticeably lifted from the floor.
Standing on the heels with the feet considerably lifted from the floor.

The hooks and dashes indicate, first, which part of the foot takes the weight, and second, how far the toes are lifted away from the floor and, hence, how much the ankle is bent. In contrast to having the weight on the balls of the feet or on the toes, in the case of the heels, the hooks and dashes do not indicate raising or lowering the whole body.
The foot positions shown in *Examples* **225 l–p** can also occur in low supports.

In standing on point (*see* **225a,g**), one supports on the actual tip of the toes. If, in exceptional cases, supporting on the toe nails must be indicated, it is written as in *Example* **225v**. *Old way of writing: Appendix I 919.
If supporting on the pads of the toes is needed, it is written as in **225w**.

outline: **225–230: Supporting on parts of the foot.** The same hooks and dashes which when added to a leg gesture indicate a touch of the floor by various parts of the foot (*see* 534) are also added to a support sign to indicate which part of the foot is taking the weight.

detail.content: *Example* **226a** shows supporting on the points of the toes, as in dancing *on point*, and *Example* **226b** shows walking with no weight on the heels, often described in everyday language as “*walking on tip-toe*”.

*Example* **226c** indicates that, from standing on the balls of the feet, one should twice go down on to the whole foot with an accent and lift again. Because one is already standing on the front part of the foot, only *the heels are dropped and make the sound*. As one can see from this example, the change of the supporting part of the foot can be expressed by placing contact signs in the support column.
*Jump* from first to second position *to land on the heels*.

*Swaying forwards and backwards* while standing on both feet. The symbols for touching the floor with the whole foot, which are written in the leg gesture columns (*see*537, 539b), indicate that neither the heels in the first movement nor the front of the foot in the second are released from the floor. The contact of the whole foot with the floor is maintained. The same movement could also be described as shifting the centre of gravity (*see* 526a). In **226f** swaying forwards, backwards, and again forwards is expressed only with contact signs, without the help of new support signs.

outline: **225–230: Supporting on parts of the foot.** The same hooks and dashes which when added to a leg gesture indicate a touch of the floor by various parts of the foot (*see* 534) are also added to a support sign to indicate which part of the foot is taking the weight.

detail.content: *Supports on bent legs. Example* **227a** shows a low knee bend (*grand piié*), in which the heels are slightly lifted from the floor. It is stressed that the heels leave the floor as little as possible. The knee bend is described by means of the centre of gravity sign (*see* 517a).
A *2/3* knee bend, supporting on the *half point*. The knee bend is expressed by means of narrow signs in the leg gesture columns (see 517a′, 662).
A *5/6* knee bend, supporting on point.

outline: **225–230: Supporting on parts of the foot.** The same hooks and dashes which when added to a leg gesture indicate a touch of the floor by various parts of the foot (*see* 534) are also added to a support sign to indicate which part of the foot is taking the weight.

detail.content: *Styles of walking*. Several different hooks and dashes added to one support sign describe the transition from one part of the foot to another. The symbols are read, like other symbols, from the bottom upwards. The gap between two contact signs shows the duration of the transition. *Other way of writing this transition: Appendix II 958.
*Everyday walking*, in which the weight passes successively from the heel to the ball of the foot.
A *dance-like walk*, in which the weight passes successively from the toes to the whole foot.
A walk in which the *whole foot is placed flat on the floor*.

The retention sign placed above the contact sign for the heel means that only the heel is supporting during the first part of the transference. The transition to supporting on the whole foot happens suddenly, and not successively as in *Examples* **228a,b**. (*Compare with* the round retention sign above contact signs, 543f, 549c,d, 582a, 786d.)

outline: **225–230: Supporting on parts of the foot.** The same hooks and dashes which when added to a leg gesture indicate a touch of the floor by various parts of the foot (*see* 534) are also added to a support sign to indicate which part of the foot is taking the weight.

detail.content: *Turning on different parts of the feet*. (*Compare with* 250.) If only one part of the foot takes the weight in a turn, the hooks or dashes can either be attached to the preceding support sign (**229a**, *turning on the heel*) or to the turn sign (**229b**, *turning on the ball of the foot*). *Example* **229c** shows the so-called *promenade* of classical ballet, a turn on the ball of the foot, which is interrupted several times by lowering the heel.

outline: **225–230: Supporting on parts of the foot.** The same hooks and dashes which when added to a leg gesture indicate a touch of the floor by various parts of the foot (*see* 534) are also added to a support sign to indicate which part of the foot is taking the weight.

detail.content: *Supporting on parts of the feet with leg rotation*. By inserting leg rotations between supporting on the ball and the heel, a progression of the body is made, although no direction signs appear in the support column to suggest it. This progression can be shown in the kinetogram by adding the symbol for a straight path containing an empty direction sign. (*Compare with* deviations, 275, and leg rotations, 396–398, 402.)

Because of the rotation of both legs to the right while supporting on the heels, and the rotation of both legs to the left while supporting on the balls of the feet, a progression to the right results.

Transition into standing on the balls of the feet, then, rotation of both legs to the right while the heels slide over the floor, followed by a change to standing on the heels, finally returning to the unrotated state of the legs while the balls slide over the floor. (*See* 550, sliding touches of the floor, and 402c, leg rotations.)

outline: **231–234: Sliding changes of support** We distinguish among four different kinds of *sliding steps and supports*: the sliding step (**231a,b**), sliding from one double position to another (*échappé*, **232**), a gliding support (**233a–c**), and a sliding hop (**234**).

detail.content: In a *sliding step* one slides into the step; the stepping foot slides over the floor while the body progresses and the whole weight (**231a**) or part of it (**231b**) is transferred. In a sliding step two hooks or dashes of the *same* kind are attached to the support sign. Two *different* hooks or dashes, however, indicate the style of placing the foot while stepping without sliding (*see* 228a,b). (*Compare with* sliding touches of the floor, 550.)
A *chassé*.
Sliding into a closed position.

outline: **231–234: Sliding changes of support** We distinguish among four different kinds of *sliding steps and supports*: the sliding step (**231a,b**), sliding from one double position to another (*échappé*, **232**), a gliding support (**233a–c**), and a sliding hop (**234**).

detail.content: An *échappé* is similar to a sliding step in so far as the feet slide into the new position. However, the body does not progress, *i.e.* the centre of gravity stays above the same spot, and there is no transference from one foot to the other, because the movement is from one double position to another. The *échappé* is a stage between a step and a jump. In order to slide from one position to the next, one must make the body light, as in a jump, and release the weight momentarily from the floor. However, one must not actually leave the floor, as in a true jump.

In the simplified way of writing an *échappé*, the support signs are written immediately following one another. From the absence of gaps in the support columns, it can be seen that the body does not leave the floor.

This example shows in detail how the previous example should be performed. The preparatory lifts of the weight, in which contact with the floor is not lost, are identified by the retention signs in the support columns, together with the action strokes in the leg gesture columns. (*Compare with* mixture of a support with a leg gesture, 221b,d, 222.) The transferences of weight which follow are sliding steps, *i.e.* the feet slide over the floor while progressing towards the ew points of support and while taking the weight. (*Compare with* 231a,b.)

outline: **231–234: Sliding changes of support** We distinguish among four different kinds of *sliding steps and supports*: the sliding step (**231a,b**), sliding from one double position to another (*échappé*, **232**), a gliding support (**233a–c**), and a sliding hop (**234**).

detail.content: In *gliding supports*, in contrast to sliding steps, no transference of weight occurs; one is standing on a foot, and this foot keeps the weight while the body as a whole progresses. The way of writing this kind of movement results from the fact that a retention and a progression occur at the same time. One can write either a retention sign within a support sign, as in **233a**, or a retention sign in the support column and a path sign containing an empty direction sign beside the kinetogram, as in **233b**. If one glides on a circular path, as in *skating*, the empty direction sign is placed in a circular path sign, as in **233c**. (*Compare with* 218c,d, 275.)

outline: **231–234: Sliding changes of support** We distinguish among four different kinds of *sliding steps and supports*: the sliding step (**231a,b**), sliding from one double position to another (*échappé*, **232**), a gliding support (**233a–c**), and a sliding hop (**234**).

detail.content: The earthbound *sliding hop* is another way of progressing on a leg which already supports the weight. In contrast to a gliding support, one lightens the body and releases the foot without taking it off the floor, and then takes weight again at the new point of support.
Two or more support signs are written immediately one after the other, because there are several shifts of weight.

In *Example* **234b** the sliding hop is described in detail. Similar to an *échappé* (232b), the preparatory lightening of the body is described as releasing part of the weight, *i.e.* as a stage between a step and a leg gesture. The following shift of weight is a sliding step; the foot slides over the floor while it travels to the new point of support, taking weight at the same time. (*Compare with* 231.)

keywords: diagonal dashes attached to short vertical lines (parts of the arms)
horizontal dashes attached to or across short vertical lines (parts of the legs)
outline: Figure 314 gives a survey of the basic types of body signs.

detail.content: Direction and turn signs in the columns of the staff are sufficient to describe progression and turns of the body as a whole, as well as the gestures and twists of the legs, arms, and upper part of the body. Thus, the principal and most frequent movements can be written simply with few symbols. (*See* 9, 896.). If more details are required about particular parts of the body and their special movements, body signs are used.
When “upper part of the body movements” are mentioned in this book, the special movements dealt with in Part F XI 412–417 are referred to.

outline: There are six basic types of body signs. First, the sign for the head (315a). Second, the signs for the parts of the arms (315b–e). Third, the signs for the parts of the legs (315f–i). Fourth, the sign for the trunk (or torso) (315j), and the signs for the sections of the trunk (315k—n) which are derived from it. Fifth, the basic sign for a limb (315o). Sixth, the basic sign used for the planes and edges of the hand and foot (315p).

Note: As a rule, one can see from the placement of the symbols on the staff whether a part of the right or left leg is referred to. In cases of doubt, parts of the left leg (315f′—i′) and the right leg (315f″–i″) can be differentiated. When included in the signs for “augmented” body sections (*see* 440a,c,e,g,h,k,l, 441a—g), the signs shown in 315f–i mean the parts of both legs.

If placed outside the columns of the staff or in a path sign, the sign for the pelvis means the centre of a group or the person at the centre (*see* “shifting the group”, 293, and “part-of-the-group” signs, 878, 879).

It should be noted that in the sign for the pelvis the black disc is placed in a square (F 315m, 418c), in the sign for the palm of the hand or sole of the foot, it is placed in a rectangle open at the bottom end (F 375b, 408b), and in the symbol for a retention on a spot (D 217d,g,h, L III 778d,g,h), it is placed in a diamond.

A symbol like a figure 8 open at the bottom is the basic symbol for a number of signs which are used in special cases to describe the inclusion of particular regions of the upper body in an arm movement. (*See* also movements of the upper part of the body, 417e.) ** Additional symbols: App. II 972.

outline: Principles for the modification of body signs. (*Compare with* 35–44.)

detail.content: Pin signs written in the head sign serve to describe the respective **parts of the head**(*see* 344).
means the right ear, this being situated at the middle of the right side of the head.

If the narrow sign is written in the head sign in conjunction with a pin sign, it serves to describe parts inside the mouth (*see* 344n,d′,g′,h′). Figure 316b means the soft palate, because this is situated in the backward-high area of the mouth.

If the wide sign is written in the head sign in conjunction with a pin sign, it serves to indicate hair on various parts of the head (*see* 344 l',m′,n′). Figure 316c means a beard growing on the chin (forward-low area of the head).
**Subdivisions of sections of the limbs.** Dots above and below the symbols for parts of the arms and legs are used to indicate the upper and lowerparts of sections of the particular limb.
A dot below a joint sign means the upper part of the section of the limb below that joint. Figure 316d means the upperpart of the left upper arm (below the shoulder).
A dot above the joint means the lower part of the section of the limb above it (*see* 360, 393). Figure 316e means the part of the right lower leg above the ankle.

**Signs for the fingers and their parts.** Dots near or within the hand sign serve to identify the fingers and their parts. Figure 316f shows the  five fingers of the right hand. The highest dot means the thumb, and the lowest dot means the little finger. In touches, one dot indicates the first knuckle (base of the finger), two dots indicate the second knuckle, and three dots the third (distal) knuckle. In movements, the sign with one dot indicates the movement of the whole finger, two dots indicate a movement of the two distal segments, and three dots indicate a movement of the most distal segment only. (*See* 362). In a touch, the sign in Figure 316g means the third (distal) knuckle of the little finger of the left hand; in a movement it indicates the movement of the distal segment of the finger.

A new method of indicating the fingers and their parts has been proposed and is under discussion. According to this proposal the sign for the fingers is written with five strokes, and the dots are placed on these strokes. With this method, 316ff means the right thumb, and 316gg means the distal joint of the little finger of the left hand. (*See* 348e,e′,e″, 363, 365.) (*Compare with* 383e,e′,e″.)

**Signs for the planes and edges of the hands and feet.** The development of these symbols starts from the assumption of a basic position in which the soles of the feet and the palms of the hands face downwards, and the tips of the fingers and toes point forwards.
The soles and palms are regarded as the under surface and, therefore, are identified by a black disc. * Old way of writing: App. I 916.
The back of the hand andtop of the foot are identified by a small circle.

The thumb and big toe edges are regarded as the inner edges and are identified by a small stroke from the inner side of the symbol, i.e. for the left foot and hand, on the right of the symbol, and vice versa. Figure 316j means the thumb edge of the right hand,or the inner edge of the right foot.

The little finger and little toe edges are regarded as the outer edges and are identified by a dot near the outer edge of the symbol. Figure 316k means the little finger edge of the right hand, or the outer edge of the right foot.
The toe and finger edges are regarded as the front edges and are identified by a small stroke at the top of the symbol.

The wrist and heel ends are regarded as the back edges andare identified by a stroke at the bottom of the symbol, which in this case is open at the top. (*See* 375, 376, 408, 409.). The symbol in 316m is derived from that in 316m′, which meansthe base of the hand or foot. *Example* 316m″ is also derived from 316m′ and means the under surface of the heel, or the wrist end of the palm.

**Modifications of the basic symbol for a limb.** The double vertical line, the basic sign for a limb, placed below a body sign signifies the body section situated below the respective joint. Accordingly, the whole arm is regarded as the limb below the shoulder (316n), and the neck as the bodysection below the head (316o). (*See* 364a,a′,a″, 395a,a′,a″). If the double vertical line is placed above a joint sign, it identifies the section of the limb above the joint, nearer the body. Figure 316p means the right forearm. A substitute for writing the double line above the joint sign is to double the vertical line of the body sign. Figure 316q meansthe same as 316p, i.e. the right forearm.
**Signs for the planes and edges of the limbs** (*see* 379, 411). These signs are understood in the same sense as those for the planes and edges of the hands and feet.
The outer surface of the arm (corresponding with the back of the hand), or the front surface of the leg (corresponding with the top of the foot).
The inner surface of the arm (corresponding with the palm), or back surface of the leg (corresponding with the sole).
The thumb edge of the right arm, or the inner surface of the right leg (big toe edge of foot).
The little finger edge of the right arm, or the outer surface of the right leg (little toe edge of the foot).
The little finger edge of the right forearm.
It should be noted that in the case of the little finger and little toe edges, only the version of 316v is possible.
The inner surface (palm side) of the right forearm.
Additional identification. In cases of doubt, the hand or foot sign can be added to or inserted in the indication for a plane or edge.
Back of the right hand.
Left sole.
Little finger edge of the right hand.

**Signs for the planes and edges of the trunk and body sections.** The common distinguishing mark of this group of signs is that all of them consist of a rectangle or square containing a black or white disc, a narrow sign, or a body sign. In this case the trunk and its sections (chest, waist, pelvis, and shoulder region) are regarded as body sections. The various planes and edges of a body section are shown by a small stroke placed at the appropriate spot on the outerline of the symbol. A stroke on the top edge means the front surface, etc.
Front plane of the chest.
Back plane of the whole trunk.
The face. (Front surface of the head as a body section.)
The knee cap. (Here the knee is regarded as a body section.) (*See* 379o–r, 411g,h, 442.)

**Symbols for the movable parts of the trunk** (*see* 443). These symbols are derived from the signs for the chest, pelvis, and waist. The black or white disc, or the narrow sign is shifted onto the appropriate edge or corner of the square.
The breast-bone (sternum).
The lumbar spine.
**Signs for the “augmented” body sections** are built up by placing in a rectangle the symbols for the two body sections or parts at the outer ends of the augmented section (*see* 440).
Section from the knees to the shoulders.
The whole body from the toes to the fingertips. These signs can only be used if all body sections involved are in one line.

In positions or movements of larger body sections of the whole body held in one line, the situation of the centre of gravity is necessarily included and need not be written (*see* The Centre of Gravity).

**Reversed body signs.** In all symbols for body sections containing two indications, the top symbol always signifies the free end of the section, and the bottom symbol signifies the fixed end. For example, in the trunk sign the chest symbol is at the top. This means that the chest end is free and the pelvic end is fixed. If the upper end of the body section is fixed and the lower end is free, the two symbols within the rectangle are reversed (*see* 427, 441).
The shoulder end of the trunk is fixed, and the lower end is free.
Upper end of pelvis (near the waist) is fixed, and the lower end is free.

keywords: body signs (parts of the body) below a direction sign
double lines between body sign and direction sign
outline: The uses of body signs—Basic rules.

detail.content: **A body sign in conjunction with a direction sign** indicates that the joint in question will be carried to a new position in space but will have no movement within itself. The movement occurs in the next joint nearer the centre of the body. The direction is judged from the joint in which the movement occurs. The body sign is always placed below the direction sign.
For example, if the elbow is lifted to the side, it will arrive to the side of the shoulder joint.
If the wrist is directed vertically up (317b), it will be above the elbow, i.e. the whole lower arm will be vertical.
The duration of the movement is from the beginning of the body sign to the end of the direction sign.

If the body sign appears in a position graph below the double starting line, it has no time value. In this case, only the direction sign indicates the duration of the movement. *Example* 317d shows tilting the body backward-high in one line from the knees to the shoulders in a kneeling position.

If the movement is very quick, the body sign can be separated from the direction sign by a double line. The double line, like the upper lines of the starting position, signifies the beginning of the movement; the body sign below it has no time value. *Example* 317e shows falling flat. From standing, the body section from the feet to the shoulders moves in one line into a horizontal situation supported on the front of the body. (*Compare with* 751.) This way of writing is needed especially for movements of augmented body sections (*see* 479a, 501f, 751c, 798e, 897d′).

If several movements of one part identified by a body sign are written in the first four columns, either the body sign must be repeated below each direction symbol (317f), or carets must be added to indicate that the direction signs which follow refer to the same body part (317g) (*see* 58, 560f).

keywords: body signs (parts of the body) below a pin sign
curving out parts of the body (bulging out parts of the body, displacing a joint)
planes and edges of the hand
pin sign in the increase sign (position sign in the increase sign)
pin sign for minute movements (position sign for minute movements, small movements)
outline: **Body signs followed by isolated pin signs mean** that the part in question performs a minute movement in the direction indicated by the pin; thus, its situation is slightly changed. If a joint moves in this way, it is slightly displaced (bulges out) in the direction of the pin. The result of such a small change of the position of a body part is maintained until the next movement is indicated for the body part in question (*see* 782o).

detail.content: The right arm is horizontally in front of the shoulder, with the thumb edge directed to the left. (Thumb edge, *see* 375d,e.) The wrist is slightly displaced upwards; the forearm remains more or less in the same direction.
The duration of such a slight displacement can be expressed by placing the pin sign in an increase sign of appropriate length. (*See* 151c, 727b, 758e.)

If the resulting wrist position should be retained during the subsequent movement, a retention sign is written above the pin sign. The slight displacement will then be retained until cancelled by a decrease sign.

The displacement of the wrist in the direction of the back of the hand, shown in *Example* 318a, can also be analysed and written as a contraction of the wrist over the front, i.e. the front side becomes concave (318d) (*see* 642a, 684a).

keywords: body signs (parts of the body) in inclusion bow
body signs (parts of the body) in a vertical bow
vertical bows with straight midddle part (inclusion bow)
curving out parts of the body (bulging out parts of the body, displacing a joint)
inclusion of the hip (participation of the hip)
planes and edges of the leg (and its parts)
outline: The uses of body signs—Basic rules.

detail.content: **A body sign within a vertical bow** means that this part “leads” the movement, i.e. in a movement of a larger unit it is the first part to move. If it is a joint, for instance the wrist as in 319a, it is displaced in the direction of the destination of the arm gesture so that the hand appears to follow with resistance (*see* 563f, 711c, 760a). (*Examples* under 355a,b, 377d, 389a—d,i, 426a,c, 432p,q.) A vertical bow containing a symbol indicatesa “passing change of state.” By the upper end of the vertical bow, the wrist will have returned to its normal situation between the forearm and fingertips (*see* 760). In Example 319b the right hip leadsa step of the right foot to the right, i.e. the right hip is displaced to the right at the beginning of the movement, but by the end it has returned to its normal situation. (*Compare with* centre of gravity leading, 527.)

**Body signs within the “inclusion bow”.** The inclusion bow is a straightened vertical bow, curved only at the ends, used to express the participation of one part of the body in the movement of another. A body sign in the centre of this bow indicates which body part participates in the movement to which the bow is added. It should be noted that the bowis interrupted to contain the body sign. (*See* 564a, 760′, 782h. *Compare with* the empty inclusion bow, 223a,b, 417a.) (*Examples* of body signs within the inclusion bow, 327c, 356b, 359d, 389f–h, 398e, 401b,d, 433a′, 437d,e, 489e,h, 501f.)

The right hip participates in the sideways step of the right leg. The movement is similar to 319b in that the hip is displaced. However, it starts to move at the same time as the whole body, and the result of its participation is that it is displaced for as long as the result of the main movement lasts, i.e. it will remain displaced during the subsequent retention (L III 782h).

If the result of the participation should last longer than the result of the main movement, a retention sign is written above the inclusion bow. In 319d the right hip will remain displaced during the subsequent two steps. The inclusion of the left hip in the last step cancels the result of the participation of the right hip in the first step. (*See* 784c, 389h.)

**Symbols for planes and edges placed in a vertical bow** express that the respective plane or edge of a bodypart “leads” the movement, i.e. that it faces the direction of the progression. In *Example* 319e the palm leads in a sequence of arm gestures. This results in a number of arm rotations; the arm rotates inwards at the beginning, then untwists, and then rotates outwards. By the end of the movement the “leading” by the palm finishes, and the arm returns to its normal untwisted state. (*Compare with* 319a,b, 783g′, 760b.) (*Examples*, 319h, 380a,c,e,g, 381a,b, 411i, 563g,h.)

If a plane or edge of the hand leads an arm gesture, a minute displacement of the wrist in the direction of the progression occurs in addition to the arm rotation. This is equally valid for those guidances written with a vertical bow (319e) or with an addition bracket (319f).

The “addition bracket” is a vertical bracket which serves to give additional indications for the performance of the movement to which it is added (*see* 562). It should be noted that the bracket is not interrupted to contain the added sign, as is the inclusion bow (*compare with* 319c,d).

**Signs for planes or edges in an addition bracket** also express that the plane or edge leads, i.e. that it faces the direction of the progression. The only difference between *Examples* 319e and f is that in f the result of a guidance, i.e. the outward rotation of the arm, is retained as long as the result of the main movement. The addition bracket means that the guidanceis an integrated part of the arm gesture. (*See* 562e, 761a, 782r.) (*Examples*, 319g,i, 380b,d,f,g′, 381a,b.)

Signs for planes and edges of the limbs placed in an addition bracket also express that the particular plane or edge faces the direction of the progression. The moving limb must rotate in such a way that this can be performed. In this example the front of the leg leads. To make this possible, the leg must first rotate in and then rotate out. (*See* 319f.)
Some colleagues use the technical terms “guide” or “guidance” for this type of leading.

In an arm gesture in a central situation (from the body centre outwards, or from the periphery inwards towards the centre), leading with a plane or edge of the hand will result in a bend of the wrist. In this example the palm leads an arm gesture forwards from “place” (*see* 116b). The palm must face forward. The more the arm extends forwards, the more the wrist will bend backwards. At the end the hand will return to its normal situation as an extension of the arm. (*See* 319e). In such a movement in a central situation, the direction of the progression is identical to a straight line towards the destination. The palm faces both the direction of the progression and the destination.

If the palm sign is written in an addition bracket in the same movement as in 319h, the palm remains directed forwards until the end of the movement, and remains so until the arm gesture is cancelled by a new indication. (*See* 319f.)

keywords: body signs (parts of the body) in conjunction with relation signs
outline: **Body signs in conjunction with relation signs.** (*See* relation signs, 528a–g.) A horizontal bow meansa touch. This example shows the right hand touching the left shoulder.

keywords: body signs (parts of the body) below space measurement signs
outline: **Space measurement signs written above body signs** indicate that the particular part stretches (lengthens) (321a), contracts (shortens) (321b), spreads (opens sideways, abducts) (321c), or closes from the side (adducts) (321d). (*See* 639, 640, 675–693.)

detail.content: Right hand stretches (lengthens)
Right hand contracts (shortens)
Right hand spreads (opens sideways, abducts)
Right hand closes from the side (adducts)
The duration of such a movement can be expressed in two ways.

If one wishes only to characterise the movement without indicating the degree of the narrowness or wideness which should be reached (technical term: stating the “motion”), the space measurement sign is placed in an increase sign of appropriate length (321e). (*See* 671, 728f,g, 758a,b.)

However, if one wishes to express the degree of narrowness or wideness that should be reached (technical term: stating the “destination”), the space measurement sign is placed above an action stroke of appropriate length and linked to it by a vertical bow (321f). (*See* 673, 759a,b,c.)

keywords: cancellation of directions for parts of the arm
cancellation of directions for the head
cancellation of directions for parts of the leg
retention in space (space hold, empty diamond)
outline: **Body signs and cancellation signs.** (*See* 79, 789.) The decrease sign is the general cancellation sign of Kinetography. It means that the body part in question returns from an unusual state to its normal carriage. Other way of writing, L III 789b,b′. *Old way of writing: App. I 917.

detail.content: In this example the head is tilted backward-high in the starting position. At the beginning of the subsequent forward bend of the trunk, the head should return to its normal situation in line with the spine.

A movement of the whole arm cancels previous special positions of the lower and upper arm. In the starting position shown here both arms are forward, then the left forearm is moved vertically upwards, and the right upper arm moves to the right (the right forearm remains forward). With the last movement the whole left arm moves left-forward, and the whole right arm moves right-forward.

A movement of the whole leg cancels previous special positions of the thigh and lower leg. In the starting position of this example the right knee is lifted forwards, and the lower leg hangs vertically down. Then the whole right leg moves right-forward, the lower leg moves vertically down, and lastly, the whole leg moves left-forward.

In *Examples* 322b and c no cancellation signs have been used. In such cases the most natural way of returning to the normal situation is understood. However, cancellation signs could be used if the return to the normal state is performed in an unusual way, e.g. if it should already be finished by the beginning of the new movement of the whole arm or leg (822d), or if the return is retarded and only finished after the completion of the main movement (322e). ** Other cancellation sign: App. II 996.

In writing with a “divided column”, thin direction signs for the upper and lower arm are placed beside one another in the arm gesture column.(*See* 120b, 352c, and *compare with* 120a, 386c, 399c′.) This has the advantage that a full width direction sign written above them gives a clear visual picture that the whole limb now moves as a unit.
A new support automatically cancels any special positions of parts of the stepping leg.

A position written with a space measurement sign placed above a body sign (*see* 321) is also cancelled by a decrease sign. The body part returns to its normal position (neither stretched nor bent). ** Other way of writing: App. II 996.
There are special cancellation signs for the return of a body part from a twisted state to its normal untwisted state, and for the cancellation of a relationship. (*See* 79b,c, 789c,c′,f).

keywords: body signs (parts of the body) with retention signs (hold signs)
retention at a spot of relationship (diamond around black disk)
retention in space (space hold, empty diamond)
retention signs above body signs (hold signs above body signs)
outline: **Body signs and retention signs** (*see* 78, 217a–i, 778a–i).

detail.content: A body retention sign placed immediately above a joint sign means the joint is rigid. This is cancelled by a decrease sign. This example shows walking with stiff knees. (*See* 788a, 357f, 371c, 390d, 434e, 435c,d, 667c,d.)
Retentions in space for the upper and lower arm. After the first turn the upper arm is to the right and the forearm is forward. With the secondturn the arm will return to its starting position.

Retention at the spot of relationship for the hands. The hands remain on the table while the trunk is inclined forwards and then raised. The hands remain on the table until their contact is cancelled by the release signs. (*See* 79c,c′, 789c,c′.)

keywords: body signs (parts of the body) below a strength measurement sign (strength measurement signs above body signs)
outline: **Strength measurementsigns with the lower end directed towards body signs indicate** the tense or dynamic quality of the movement of the respective parts. (*See* 715, 716.)

detail.content: The hand is relaxed.
A small jerk of the handto theleft. (*See* 151b.)

keywords: body signs (parts of the body) in support columns
outline: **Body signs in the support columns** indicate that the particular body parts take the weight. This example shows kneeling. Supporting on parts of the body is dealt with in Part G.

**Direction signs for the head** refer to the main axis of the head, i.e. the line from the first cervical vertebra (top vertebra of the neck) to the centre of the crown. The basic principle is that directions for the head relate to the front of the trunk (i.e. in a twisted position, to the front of the shoulder section) unless another relationship is indicated by a clef. (*See* 343.)

detail.content: The basic position of the head in standing or in lying is in line with the spine. In standing, this means that it is high with the face forward.
In tilts of the head, the top of the spine bends. If it tilts forward-high, the face is forward-low and the neck is bent.
The head is tilted horizontally forward: the face is down. The neck and dorsal spine are involved.
The head is tilted to the right; the face remains forward. Again the neck and dorsal spine are involved.
The head is tilted backward-high; the face is forward-high. Only the neck is involved.
Rolling the head around counterclockwise; the whole neck is involved.
Rolling the head with a slight circling of the upper spine.

keywords: body signs (parts of the body) with retention signs (hold signs)
vertical bows with straight midddle part (inclusion bow)
letter C (head sign) in inclusion bow
the head in upper body movements
inclusion of the head (participation of the head)
upper body (upper part of the body)
outline: **The head in “upper body” movements.**(*See* movements of the “upper part of the body”, 412–417.)

detail.content: In inclinations of the upper part of the body, the head is slightly carried along, but its movementis hardly noticeable.
If the head should remain exactly vertical, a “space hold” is written (*see* 217c,f, 323b).
If the head is to sway with the upper body, one writes that it is “included”. (*See* inclusion bow, 56, 319c,d, 564a.)
If the headis tilted in the samedirection as the arm,this mustbe specially written.

keywords: the head in tilts of the trunk (the head in tilts of the torso)
outline: **The head in tilts of the whole trunk, chest, and shoulder section.** (*See* trunk movements, 418 onwards.)

detail.content: In inclinations of the trunk, chest, and shoulder section, the head is carried along because its normal situation is in line with the spine, or more exactly, with the part of the spine belonging to the shoulder section.
If the head should remain erect, the sign for retention in space is written (*see* 217c,f, 323b).

keywords: cancellation of directions for the head
the head in tilts of the trunk (the head in tilts of the torso)

detail.content: In an upright position of the trunk, the return of the head to its normal carriage can be written with a high direction sign.

In tilts of the trunk, the return of the head to its normal position in line with the spine is written with the same direction sign as that of the trunk inclination. The starting position of 329b is with the trunk forward and the head up. The head then tilts forward into line with the spine.
The same movement as 329b. Use of the cancellation sign (decrease sign) is another way of writing the head movement.
If the trunk (329e) or the upper part of the body (329d) is raised, the head returns with it to the upright position.

keywords: pin sign indicating shifts (position sign indicating shifts)
pin sign for minute movements (position sign for minute movements)
outline: **“Shifting” the head** is the displacement of the head while it remains upright. It is indicated by a high direction sign with the addition of a pin sign. This way of writing expresses that the movement is a changeof the situation of the head and not of its direction. The head can also shift if it is tilted, in which case the pin is added to the appropriate direction sign. The pin sign indicates the situation of the head in relation to its own normal situation. (*Compare with* 148; shifting the chest, 423d,e, the pelvis, 423f, and centre of gravity, 423c, 488f, 526a.) ** Other way of writing: App. II 957a.

keywords: pin sign for minute movements (position sign for minute movements, small movements)
outline: **Nodding the head.** Small nodding movements are written with pin signs. (*See* 151a—c.) (*Compare with* 526b, 424.)

keywords: body signs (parts of the body) with retention signs (hold signs)
retention at a spot (spot hold, diamond around black disk)
the head in tilts of the trunk (the head in tilts of the torso)
retention signs in vertical brackets (hold signs in vertical brackets)
outline: **Retentions for the head.** (*See* 217, 778.)

detail.content: The head is tilted forwards before the turn; as a result of the space retention it will be backwards after the turn.
In this example the head must perform appropriate counter movements in order to remain at the same spot while the rest of the body moves about.

To avoid the repetitions of the sign for retention at a spot, one sign can be placed in an addition bracket of appropriate length. (*See* 562h, 357d, 543i, 779c.) ** Other way of writing: App. II 993.
In the starting position the trunk is forward and the head is forward-high. The result of the retention in the body is that the head will be backward-high when the trunk is erect.

keywords: turns around the chief axis of a body part
untwisted (unrotated, cancellation of rotation, turn neither to the right nor left)
outline: **Turns of the head.** In head turns, the principle is that the ordinary turn sign means a turn of the head around its own chief axis (i.e. the line from the top neck vertebra to the centre of the crown), unless a turn around another axis is explicitly indicated by a clef (*see* 343o–q).

detail.content: Head turn to the left.
Head turn to the right.
A return to the normal, unrotated position. ** Other way of writing: App. II 965.

keywords: degree of turn or twist (amount of turn or twist)
black pin sign in turn signs (black position sign in turn signs)
flat pin sign in turn signs (flat position sign in turn signs)
white pin sign in turn signs (white position sign in turn signs, sign for twist)
turns to a common front (turns in relation to constant axes, turns relating to areas of the room)
outline: The degree of the turn (*see* 152).

detail.content: In turns of body parts, the degree of the turn is usually expressed by white pin signs. These indicate the degree of the twist, i.e. how far the body part is rotated away from its normal unrotated position. In this example the head is turned towards the right shoulder. The pin sign indicates which finishing position should be reached. This is analogous to the meaning of a direction sign written in a gesture column, i.e. the direction sign also indicates the finishing position of the body part in question. (*See* 152c, 258e, 397a–f, 432a, 439d–f.) * Old way of writing: App. I 905.
Black pin signs within turn signs indicate the degree of the turn, i.e. the degree of the rotary motion. In this example the head makes a 1/4 turn to the right.

If the head starts in the normal unrotated position, Figuress 334a and b give the same result. However, if the head is already rotated, the black and white pins are not interchangeable. In *Example* 334c the headis turned to the right and then to right-forward. *Example* 334d shows the same two movements written with black pin signs, i.e. at first a 1/4 turn to the right, and then, from the resulting position, a 1/8 turn to the left.

If the head is rotated to and fro, the transition through the normal unrotated position can be written (334e). However, this is not necessary, because the way of writing in 334f can only have the same meaning.

Flat pin signs within turn signs indicate a relationship to the axes of a defined space. This way of writing is particularly necessary if the front of the performer at the moment of the rotation is unknown, e.g. if he is in the middle of performing a turn. *Example* 334g means that the face is first turned to the right side of the room (parallel to the right—left axis of the room), and then to the foreground (parallel to the front—back axis). The whole body is shown to be facing right-forward during these movements. (*See* 152b, 258c, and *compare with* 289, 432c, 491d, 493h.)
This is the same movementas in 334g, but the degree of the twist is indicated in the usual way.

keywords: relating to the front of individual body sections (front-of-twisted-part key)

detail.content: Tilts of the rotated head are related to the front of the trunk as long as no other relationshipis stated (*see* 343). If the trunk or its parts (chest, shoulder section) are twisted, the basic rule should be supplemented to state that the relationship is to the front of the free end of the trunk, i.e. the front of the shoulder section (*see* 337). ** Other writing rule: App. II 1002 I–VI. According to this basic rule the same signs are written and the same position reached if the head is first rotated and then tilted (335a), or is first tilted and then rotated (335b), or if both movements are performed at the same time (335c).

In *Example* 335c, during the turn the head travels on the shortest path to the destination, i.e. it performs an “undeviating curve”. This need not be written with a direction sign containing a space retention sign (*compare with* 252b), because the relationship of the direction of the head movement to the front of the trunk is valid according to the basic rule.

A spiral (skew) head tilt can be indicdted by placing the symbol (clef) for the relationship to the front of individual body sections (N 889e) below the direction sign. In this case the direction of the head is in relation to its own front, which is constantly changing. The face is always directed towards the direction of the progression. A second way of writing a spiral head tilt is shown in 343m.

In *Example* 359n, a twist of the body section from the pelvis to the head is shown, in which the head rotates more than the shoulder section. In this exceptional case the direction of the face and not the front of the shoulder section is the front of the free end of the augmented body section.

keywords: neither outward nor inward rotation, neither to the right nor to the left
outline: Cancellation of a tilt and rotation. The return to the normal position after a tilt and a twist is written separately (336a), because the head may remain rotated while it is raised (336b), or may remain tilted while it rotates back to normal (336c).

Rotation andt ilts of the head while the trunk is twisted. (Rotations of the trunk, *see* 432). In trunk rotations the head is carried along. “In front” for the head is the new front of the shoulder section. In Figure 337, after the trunk twist the head tilts towards the right shoulder and rotates to the right side of the body at the same time. As a result, one looks towards the heels.

keywords: letter C (head sign) in a square
letter C (head sign) in a square with stroke (planes and edges of the head)
square with a body sign (body sign in a square)
outline: **The planes and edges of the head.**

detail.content: The head sign within a square means the head as a body section. This sign is only used as part of more differentiated symbols, because a movement of this body section is identical to a head movement written with the simple head sign. (*See* *Examples* 329–337.) * Old meaning of this sign: App. I 923b.

In this example the symbol for the head as a bodysection is used as part of the symbol for a larger body section, i.e. the section from the hip joint to the crown of the head. (Additional symbols of this type, *see* 418h,k, 427b,d,e, 440g.) In a tilt this symbol means that the head remains in line with the other body sections indicated, and in turns it means that the head turns further than the shoulder section. (*See* 433b, 435b,d,e,f, 437c.)
The signs for the planes and edges of the head are derived from the symbol for the head as a body section.
The face. * Old way of writing: App. I 923.
The right surface of the head.
The left edge of the face.

keywords: letter C (head sign) in a square with stroke (planes and edges of the head)
outline: **The direction of the plane of the face.**

detail.content: In standing,the basic position is with the head upright and the face forward.

Some directions of the face involve a tilt of the head. If the face is forward-high (339b), the head is tilted backward-high, and if the face is forward-low (339c), the head is forward-high. These tilts should only involve the top of the neck.

Sideways and diagonal directions of the face involve rotations of the head. Directing the face to the right (339d) and a 1/4 turn of the head to the right (234a,b) are both ways of expressing the same movement. One should choose the way of writing which is the most appropriate in the context.

Some diagonal face directions involve both a tilt and a rotation. It should be noted that in such cases directing the face does not give an unambiguous description of the intended movement and resulting position, because one can produce the facing direction in various ways. Directing the face right-forward-low (339e) can be done by tilting the head right-forward-high plus rotating 1/8 to the right (339f), or also by a simple tilt of the head left-forward (339h). Finally, a forward-high tilt of the head in combination with a 1/8 rotation to the right (339g) results in a direction of the face similar to that in 339f. This can also be regarded as directing the face towards right-forward-low.
If the head turns to and fro, it is wise to insert the return of the face to its normal forward direction

keywords: letter C (head sign) in a square with stroke (planes and edges of the head)
cancellation of directions for the face
outline: The cancellation of a direction for the face.

detail.content: The cancellation of a direction for the face can be either by directing the face forward,
or by the general cancellation sign.
If the direction of the face has been caused by a head rotation, the return of the head to the normal unrotated position means the cancellation of the face direction.

keywords: letter C (head sign) in a square with stroke (planes and edges of the head)
retention at a spot of relationship (diamond around black disk)
retention in space (space hold, empty diamond)
outline: **Retentions for the face** (*see* 217, 778).

detail.content: A retention in the body for the face while the trunk tilts. The face is forward-low in the starting and finishing positions, but it is backward-low after the tilt of the trunk.

If the face has a retention in space while the body turns, the head does not participate in the turn. In this example the face is and remains directed towards the foreground. (*Compare with* the retention in space for the front of the shoulder section, 398f, of the chest, 442w, and of the pelvis, 401c.)

The symbol for retention at a spot, written above an “addressing” sign for the face expresses a retention at the spot of relationship (*see* 78d). In 341c the face is towards a partner and must remain so; one should follow the partner “with the eyes”. (“Addressing”, *see* 605–612.)

outline: **Unusual rotations of the head.** (*Compare with* analogous rotations of the pelvis, 438b–d.)

detail.content: A “somersault” of the head means a rotation around its lateral axis (line from ear to ear).

In a forward somersault (*see* 500a) the neck bulges out backwards so that the axis of the rotation and the head as a whole remain at the same spot. The same movement can also be described as a contraction of the front of the neck, in which the front of the neck becomes concave. (*See* 691a.)
In a backward somersault (*see* 500b) the neck bulges out forwards. The same movement can be expressed as a contraction of the back of the neck. (*See* 691b.)
A “cartwheel” of the head means a rotation around its sagittal axis (from the nose to the base of the skull).

Ina cartwheel to the right (*see* 496b), the neck bulges out to the left so that the axis of the rotation and the head as a whole remain on the samespot. This can also be expressed as a contraction of the right side of the neck, in which this side becomes concave(*see* 691c).
In a cartwheel to the left (*see* 496a), the neck bulges out to the right. This can also be expressed as a contraction of the left side of the neck. (*See* 691d.)

keywords: axes of individual body parts (body-twisted-part key)
constant axes, axes of a room
relating to the front of the performer (standard cross of axes)
black pin sign in turn signs (black position sign in turn signs)
white pin sign in turn signs (white position sign in turn signs)
turn signs with body axes sign
turns relating to the standard cross of axes (turns around a vertical axis)
outline: **Use of “clefs” in the notation of head movements.** (*See* 889 and *compare with* 359g—m.)

detail.content: In some cases it is advisable to relate the direction of head tilts to the axes of the head and not to the front of the shoulder section (*see* basic rule 326). This is expressed by the symbol for axes of individual body parts (*see* 889d, 124d). This relationship means that the direction signs indicate which plane or edge of the head tilts towards the trunk.
The face inclines 45 degrees towards the trunk.
The left side of the head inclines 45 degrees towards the trunk.
The back of the head inclines 45 degrees towards the trunk.
The right edge of the face inclines 45 degrees towardsthe trunk.

In a kinetogram using this key, if the whole body, or the trunk, chest, or shoulder section is not upright, the actual direction of the head in relation to the front of the body is not shown in the kinetogram. It must be concluded from the context.
Chest section forward-high, face inclined 45 degrees towards it; the actual direction of the head is horizontally forward.
Trunk horizontally forward, right side of the head inclined 45 degrees towards it; the actual direction of the head is right-forward.
Chest section forward-high, back of the head inclined towards it; the actual direction of the head is upward.
Shoulder section right-high, right side of the head inclined towardsit; the actual direction of the head is to the right.

The way of writing dealt with in 343a—h is helpful in cases in which a head movement is performed while the body as a whole, the trunk, or the chest is moving, and therefore, the actual directions of the head are difficult to define. This way of writing is also to be preferred if the whole body, trunk, or chest is in a diagonal position. *Example* 343i shows lying on the right edge of the back, with the left side of the head inclined towards the trunk. In this case the direction of the head in relation to the “front” is difficult to define, while its relation to the body, i.e. the inclination towards the left shoulder, is easily recognised.

The directions of the head shown in *Examples* 335a—c are written in relation to the axes of the head. In 343j, after the head rotation the face inclines towards the trunk. In 343k the right side of the head inclines towards the trunk, and then the head rotates to the right. In 343l the head inclines towards the right shoulder in an “undeviating curve” (*see* 252a,b, 253b), while it rotates to the right. The inclination of the right side of the head at the beginning of the movement becomes an inclination of the face by the end. As in *Examples* 335a—c the finishing positions of 343j–l are identical.

If a plane or edge of the head continues to incline while the head rotates, a spiral tilt will be produced. (*Compare with* the spiral trunk tilt in 432h.) It should be noted that the spiral head tilt can only be expressed by means of a cross of axes sign (clef), either by reference to axes of individual body parts, as in this example, or by reference to the front of individual body sections, as in 335d.

Relating to constant axes. In this example five people are arranged in a circle facing the centre. Everyone directs the head towards the foreground, slanting upwards. The actual direction of the head will depend on the front of the individual performer. (*Compare with* deviation towards a side of the room, 274a—c.)

Head wheeling. In head circling there is a constant change in the plane and edge of the head which inclines towards the trunk. In Figures 326f and first the face, then the left side, then the back, and finally the right side of the head incline towards the trunk. In head wheeling, this change is avoided by a rotation of the head which corresponds in direction and degree of rotation to the direction and degree of the circling. The same plane or edge of the head is always inclined towards the trunk. In *Examples* 343o—q it is the face which remains inclined.

If the trunk is upright, head wheeling can be written as a rotation around a vertical axis. This is done by placing the sign for the standard cross of axes in the turn sign. *Examples* 343o and p show the same movement sequence. (*Compare with* trunk wheeling, 432k,n, wheeling of the chest, 436a, and body wheeling, 493.)

In 343o the degree of the twist is indicated by white pin signs (*see* 334a). From the normal unrotated position the head wheels 1/8 to the right until it is right-forward-high, then it wheels in the opposite direction until it is left-forward-high and rotated 1/8 to the left, and finally it wheels back to the unrotated starting position. ** Other way of writing: App. II 960l.

In 343p the degree of the wheeling motion is indicated by black pin signs (*see* 334b). This example means 45 degrees of wheeling to the right, 90 degrees to the left, and then 45 degrees to the right.

If the trunk is not upright, head wheeling can be analysed as circling around the extension of the chief axis of the body (line of the spine). This is expressed by placing the sign for the cross of the body axes in the turn sign. This example shows the head wheeling sequence of 343o and p, but in this case the trunk is inclined forward.

keywords: letter C (head sign) with pin signs
corners of the mouth (sides of the mouth)
letter C (head sign) with a narrow sign
